<div class="item" data-value="1">National</div><div class="item" data-value="2">Alabama</div><div class="item" data-value="3">Alaska</div><div class="item" data-value="4">Arizona</div><div class="item" data-value="5">Arkansas</div><div class="item" data-value="6">California</div><div class="item" data-value="7">Colorado</div><div class="item" data-value="8">Connecticut</div><div class="item" data-value="9">Delaware</div><div class="item" data-value="10">District of Columbia</div><div class="item" data-value="11">Florida</div><div class="item" data-value="13">Georgia</div><div class="item" data-value="12">Guam</div><div class="item" data-value="14">Hawaii</div><div class="item" data-value="15">Idaho</div><div class="item" data-value="16">Illinois</div><div class="item" data-value="17">Indiana</div><div class="item" data-value="18">Iowa</div><div class="item" data-value="19">Kansas</div><div class="item" data-value="20">Kentucky</div><div class="item" data-value="21">Louisiana</div><div class="item" data-value="22">Maine</div><div class="item" data-value="23">Maryland</div><div class="item" data-value="24">Massachusetts</div><div class="item" data-value="25">Michigan</div><div class="item" data-value="26">Minnesota</div><div class="item" data-value="27">Mississippi</div><div class="item" data-value="28">Missouri</div><div class="item" data-value="29">Montana</div><div class="item" data-value="30">Nebraska</div><div class="item" data-value="31">Nevada</div><div class="item" data-value="32">New Hampshire</div><div class="item" </div> </div> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md-12"> <p class="m-t-25 m-b-25">What information do you want to see?</p> </div> </div> <div class="row" id="filters"> <div class="col-md-12"> <div class="form-check"> <input class="form-check-input" type="checkbox" value="1" id="stay_at_home_order" name="stay_at_home_order" checked> <label class="label_for_filter" class="form-check-label" for="stay_at_home_order"> Stay at Home Order </label> </div> <div class="form-check"> <input class="form-check-input" type="checkbox" value="1" id="guidelines_for_employers" name="guidelines_for_employers" checked> <label class="label_for_filter" class="form-check-label" for="guidelines_for_employers"> Guidelines for Employers </label> </div> <div class="form-check"> <input class="form-check-input" type="checkbox" value="1" id="other_information" name="other_information" checked> <label class="label_for_filter" class="form-check-label" for="other_information"> Other Information </label> </div>
<div class="search_btns"> <button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Filter Guidelines')" type="submit" class="btn-search">Filter Guidelines</button> <button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Reset Filters')" type="button" id="reset_filters" class="btn-reset">Reset Filters</button> </div>
</div> </div> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md-12"> <hr class="hr-new"> </div> </div> </form> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md-12"> <div class="hbtns"> <button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Expand All')" id="expand_all" class="btn-default"><img src="./images/expand.svg" alt="Expand all" /> <span>Expand all</span></button> <button onclick="$('#result').print();handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Print');" class="btn-default"><img src="./images/print.svg" alt="Print" /> Print</button> <a onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on FAQ')" href="./faq-national-reopen-guidelines-directory" class="btn-default float-right" target="_blank"><img src="./images/faq.svg" alt="Faq" /> FAQ</a> </div> <div class="clearfix"></div> <div id="result">
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on National')" data-value="1" class="collapsible">National</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> N/A </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right">N/A</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/openingamerica/" target="_blank"> Opening America </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Information coming soon </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> CDC: Businesses and employers can prevent and slow the spread of COVID-19. Employers should plan to respond in a flexible way to varying levels of disease transmission in the community and be prepared to refine their business response plans as needed. According to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), most American workers will likely experience low (caution) or medium exposure risk levels at their job or place of employment (see OSHA guidance for employers for more information about job risk classifications).<br /> <br /> Businesses are strongly encouraged to coordinate with state external icon and local external icon health officials so timely and accurate information can guide appropriate responses. Local conditions will influence the decisions that public health officials make regarding community-level strategies. CDC has guidance for mitigation strategies according to the level of community transmission or impact of COVID-19.<br /> <br /> All employers need to consider how best to decrease the spread of COVID-19 and lower the impact in their workplace. This may include activities in one or more of the following areas:<br /> <br /> 1. reduce transmission among employees,<br /> 2. maintain healthy business operations, and<br /> 3. maintain a healthy work environment. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. If implementing in-person health checks, conduct them safely and respectfully. Employers may use social distancing, barrier or partition controls, or personal protective equipment (PPE) to protect the screener. However, reliance on PPE alone is a less effective control and is more difficult to implement, given PPE shortages and training requirements.<br /> 2. Complete the health checks in a way that helps maintain social distancing guidelines, such as providing multiple screening entries into the building.<br /> 3. Follow guidance from the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission External icon regarding confidentiality of medical records from health checks.<br /> 4. To prevent stigma and discrimination in the workplace, make employee health screenings as private as possible. Do not make determinations of risk based on race or country of origin and be sure to maintain confidentiality of each individual's medical status and history. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> OSHA:<br /> 1. Low Risk of Exposure Jobs: Additional PPE is not recommended for workers in the lower exposure risk group. Workers should continue to use the PPE,<br /> if any, that they would ordinarily use for other job tasks.<br /> 2. Medium Risk of Exposure Jobs: Workers with medium exposure risk may need to wear some combination of gloves, a gown, a face mask, and/or a face shield or goggles. PPE ensembles for workers in the medium exposure risk category will vary by work task, the results of the employer's hazard assessment, and the types of exposures workers have on the job.<br /> 3. High or Very High Risk of Exposure Jobs: Most workers at high or very high exposure risk likely need to wear gloves, a gown, a face shield or goggles, and either a face mask or a respirator, depending on their job tasks and exposure risks. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> CDC: <br /> Social distancing should be implemented if recommended by state and local health authorities. Social distancing means avoiding large gatherings and maintaining distance (approximately 6 feet or 2 meters) from others when possible (e.g., break rooms and cafeterias). Strategies that business could use include:<br /> <br /> 1. Implementing flexible worksites (e.g., telework)<br /> 2. Implementing flexible work hours (e.g., staggered shifts)<br /> 3. Increasing physical space between employees at the worksite<br /> 4. Increasing physical space between employees and customers (e.g., drive through, partitions)<br /> 5. Implementing flexible meeting and travel options (e.g., postpone non-essential meetings or events)<br /> 6. Downsizing operations<br /> 7. Delivering services remotely (e.g. phone, video, or web)<br /> 8. Delivering products through curbside pick-up or delivery </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> CDC:<br /> 1. Provide tissues and no-touch disposal receptacles.<br /> 2. Provide soap and water in the workplace. If soap and water are not readily available, use alcohol-based hand sanitizer that is at least 60% alcohol. If hands are visibly dirty, soap and water should be chosen over hand sanitizer. Ensure that adequate supplies are maintained.<br /> 3. Place hand sanitizers in multiple locations to encourage hand hygiene.<br /> 4. Place posters that encourage hand hygiene to help stop the spread at the entrance to your workplace and in other workplace areas where they are likely to be seen.<br /> 5. Discourage handshaking - encourage the use of other non contact methods of greeting.<br /> 6. Direct employees to visit the coughing and sneezing etiquette and clean hands webpage for more information. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> CDC: <br /> 1. Routinely clean and disinfect all frequently touched surfaces in the workplace, such as workstations, keyboards, telephones, handrails, and doorknobs. If surfaces are dirty, they should be cleaned using a detergent or soap and water prior to disinfection.<br /> 2. For disinfection, most common EPA-registered household disinfectants should be effective. Follow the manufacturer's instructions for all cleaning and disinfection products (e.g., concentration, application method and contact time, etc.).<br /> 3. Discourage workers from using other workers' phones, desks, offices, or other work tools and equipment, when possible. If necessary, clean and disinfect them before and after use.<br /> 4. Provide disposable wipes so that commonly used surfaces (for example, doorknobs, keyboards, remote controls, desks, other work tools and equipment) can be wiped down by employees before each use. To disinfect, use products that meet EPA's criteria for use against SARS-Cov-2, the cause of COVID-19, and are appropriate for the surface. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> If an employee is confirmed to have COVID-19 infection, employers should inform fellow employees of their possible exposure to COVID-19 in the workplace but maintain confidentiality as required by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). The employer should instruct fellow employees about how to proceed based on the CDC Public Health Recommendations for Community-Related Exposure. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>N/A</strong><br> N/A </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> N/A </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.dol.gov/agencies/whd/pandemic/ffcra-employee-paid-leave"> Families First Coronaviurs Response Act </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-05-19 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html"> Interim Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.osha.gov/Publications/OSHA3990.pdf"> Guidance on Preparing Workplaces for COVID-19pdf </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Alabama')" data-value="2" class="collapsible">Alabama</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home order expired - Reopening in progress </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/05/Safer-at-Home-Order-FINAL-5.8.2020.pdf" target="_blank"> Safer at Home Executive Order </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://ltgov.alabama.gov/reopen-alabama-responsibly/" target="_blank"> Reopen Alabama Responsibly </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now: <br /> 1. Outdoor and recreation Beaches - (maintain a consistent six-foot distance.)<br /> 2. Gyms - (must follow social distancing and hygiene measures. Access must be limited to 50% of normal occupancy.)<br /> 3. Retail stores - (operate with 50% capacity.)<br /> 4. Food and drink, restaurant dining, bars and breweries - (party size to no more than 8 people and maintain) at least 6 feet between people seated at different tables, booths, chairs and stools.<br /> 5. Personal care and salons - (maintain six-foot distance, cover nostrils and mouth with mask, and wash hands before providing services, and to the extent wear gloves when providing services within 6 feet of a client when providing nail and facial services.)<br /> 6. Entertainment venues - (maintain six-foot distance, operate with 50% capacity, wear masks at all times, and regularly disinfect frequently used items and surfaces.) </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> It is strongly recommended that all businesses follow applicable Covid-19-related safety guidelines from the Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) publication, Reopening Guidance for Cleaning and Disinfecting Public Spaces, Workplaces, Businesses, Schools, and Homes, at https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/reopen-guidance.html </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Screen all employees reporting to work for COVID-19 symptoms with the following questions: <br /> 1. Have you been in close contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19?<br /> 2. Are you experiencing a cough, shortness of breath or sore throat?<br /> 3. Have you had a fever in the last 48 hours?<br /> 4. Have you experienced new loss of taste or smell?<br /> 5. Have you experienced vomiting or diarrhea in the last 24 hours?<br /> 6. Best practice: employers should take temperatures onsite with a no-touch thermometer each day upon a person's arrival at work<br /> 7. Minimum practice: an employee may take his or her temperature before arriving. In either case, a normal temperature does not exceed 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit<br /> 8. Direct any employee who exhibits COVID-19 symptoms, who answers yes to any of the screening questions or who is running a fever, to leave the premises immediately and seek medical care or COVID-19 testing or both. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> 1. Employees should wear a cloth face covering (not an N-95 or medical mask, which should be reserved for healthcare workers) while at work and in public to help protect against the spread of the virus.<br /> 2. Each employee shall wear a mask, or other facial covering that covers his or her nostrils and mouth, at all times while providing services within 6 feet of a client. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> Effective May 11, 2020, and unless otherwise permitted or required by this order, all employers shall take reasonable steps, where practicable as work duties permit, to protect their employees by:<br /> 1. Maintain six feet of separation between employees<br /> 2. Minimize employee travel </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Provide a place to wash hands or alcohol-based hand rubs containing at least 60% alcohol.<br /> 2. Train workers in proper hygiene practices.<br /> 3. Employees will have access to hand sanitizer or a place to wash their hands.<br /> 4. Point of sale equipment will be frequently cleaned and sanitized.<br /> 5. The entrance/exit doors will be sanitized routinely. <br /> 7. Customers will be required to use hand sanitizer upon entering the store. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Employees will be required to take reasonable steps to comply with guidelines on sanitation from the Center for Disease Control and Prevention and the Alabama Department of Public Health. <br /> 2. Point of sale equipment will be frequently cleaned and sanitized.<br /> 3. The entrance/exit doors will be sanitized routinely.<br /> 4. Regularly disinfecting frequently used items and surfaces every two hours.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Stay home when feeling ill, when exposed to COVID-19, or if diagnosed with a confirmed case of COVID-19. <br /> 2. People who are particularly vulnerable to COVID-19, such as people 65 or older or people with heart disease, diabetes, or other chronic conditions, are encouraged to work from home. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Dental, medical, or surgical procedures may proceed unless the State Health Officer or his designee determines that performing such procedures, or any category of them, would unacceptably reduce access to personal protective equipment or other resources necessary to diagnose and treat COVID-19. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Ordered closed for the academic year </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.labor.alabama.gov/COVID/Coronavirus%20and%20Unemployment%20Insurance%20Benefits%20UPDATED%20FAQ.pdf"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-15 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://alabamapublichealth.gov/covid19/assets/cov-sah-businesses.pdf"> Guidelines for all Businesses </a><a target="_blank" href="https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/05/Safer-at-Home-Order-FINAL-5.8.2020.pdf"> Safer at Home Order </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Alaska')" data-value="3" class="collapsible">Alaska</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home order expired - Reopening in progress </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/05212020-Phase-III-IV-Guidance.pdf" target="_blank"> Reopen Alaska Responsibly Phase 3 </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://covid19.alaska.gov/reopen/" target="_blank"> Reopen Alaska Responsibly </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Food and drink Restaurant dining: (Operate with 50% capacity and only people who live together can share a table)<br /> 3. Bars: (Operate with 25% capacity, tables must be ten feet from one another, if sitting at the bar maintain six-foot distance, and only people who live together can share a table)<br /> 4. Retail stores: (Operate with 50% capacity)<br /> 5. Personal care Hair salons, barbershops, nail salons etc. (Operate with 50% capacity)<br /> 6. Outdoor and recreation Gyms; Pools<br /> 7. Entertainment Libraries; Theaters; Bowling alleys; Museums: (Operate with 25% capacity) <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Before businesses open or expand, they should work through relevant CDC guidance and decision trees. They are also encouraged to follow new industry standards, business best practices, and compliance with local mandates or restrictions. Industry specific guidance can be found here: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/05212020-Phase-III-IV-Guidance.pdf. <br /> <br /> Core practices that should remain in place for all industries once facilities begin to reopen include: <br /> 1. Plan for visitor restrictions<br /> 2. Designate an infection control person to provide on-site management of infection control program<br /> 3. Have a plan for testing both residents and staff<br /> 4. Provide ongoing education to residents, staff, and visitors about COVID-19 and protective measures, including not having staff to work when ill<br /> 5. Have a staff management plan that includes non-punitive and flexible sick leave policies, staffing patterns in case of restrictions or shortage, and pre-shift screening<br /> 6. Provide supplies needed to adhere to infection prevention and control practices, including hand hygiene supplies, PPE, environmental cleaning and disinfection with EPA registered, hospital-grade disinfectants<br /> 7. Have a plan for management of persons who are COVID-positive or status unknown which includes isolation areas, increased monitoring, and use of N95 respirators </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Have a plan for testing both residents and staff. If an active employee is identified as being COVID-19 positive by testing, CDC cleaning and disinfecting must be performed as soon after the confirmation of a positive test as practical. In lieu of performing CDC cleaning and disinfecting, businesses may shut down for a period of at least 72 consecutive hours to allow for natural deactivation of the virus, followed by site personnel performing a comprehensive disinfection of all common surfaces. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Consider pre-shift screening of staff for symptoms (while protecting staff privacy).<br /> 2. Encourage sick staff to stay home and provide a sick leave policy that is flexible. and non-punitive, as well as telework policies where possible.<br /> 3. Establish an action plan in the event that someone becomes sick -- this should include contact tracing and notifications, notification of authorities, and closing and properly disinfecting affected areas. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Provide supplies needed to adhere to infection prevention and control practices, including hand hygiene supplies, PPE, environmental cleaning and disinfection with EPA registered, hospital-grade disinfectants. It is encouraged that cloth face coverings be worn by all employees interacting with the public. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Social distancing of at least six feet continues to be a best practice. Persons with symptoms consistent with COVID-19 should not be on the premises. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Handwashing capability or sanitizer availability is encouraged.<br /> 2. Employees should frequently wash their hands. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. It is recommended that cleaning and disinfecting continue to be conducted in compliance with CDC protocols.<br /> 2. When an active employee is identified as being COVID-19 positive by testing, CDC cleaning and disinfecting must be performed as soon after the confirmation of a positive test as practical. In lieu of performing CDC cleaning and disinfecting, restaurant businesses may shut down for a period of at least 72 consecutive hours to allow for natural deactivation of the virus, followed by site personnel performing a comprehensive disinfection of all common surfaces.<br /> 3. CDC protocols can be found online at: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidancebusiness-response.html and https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/disinfecting-building-facility.html. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. When an active employee is identified as being COVID-19 positive by testing, CDC cleaning and disinfecting must be performed as soon after the confirmation of a positive test as practical. In lieu of performing CDC cleaning and disinfecting, restaurant businesses may shut down for a period of at least 72 consecutive hours to allow for natural deactivation of the virus, followed by site personnel performing a comprehensive disinfection of all common surfaces. <br /> 2. No employee displaying symptoms of COVID-19 may provide services to customers. Symptomatic or ill employees may not report to work. <br /> 3. No employee may report to the work site within 72 hours of exhibiting a fever. <br /> 4. Employer must establish a plan for employees getting ill and a return-to work plan following CDC guidance, which can be found online at: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-businessresponse.html. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Surgeries and intensive procedures are permitted to proceed if delay is deemed to cause significant impact on health, livelihood, or quality of life, if certain precautions are taken. For details, see: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/05192020-COVID-MANDATE-015-REVISED.pdf </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Ordered closed for the academic year </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.dol.gov/agencies/whd/pandemic/ffcra-employer-paid-leave"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-15 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/05212020-Phase-III-IV-Guidance.pdf"> Phase III Guidance </a><a target="_blank" href="https://covid19.alaska.gov/reopen/"> Reopen Alaska Responsibly </a><a target="_blank" href="https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/05072020-Phase-II-016-Attachment-H-Non-Essential-Non-Public-Facing-Businesses.pdf"> Non-Essential Non-Public Facing Businesses Generally </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Arizona')" data-value="4" class="collapsible">Arizona</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home order expired - Reopening in progress </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://azgovernor.gov/executive-orders" target="_blank"> Returning Stronger Executive Order </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/covidpresentation42220finalweb.pdf" target="_blank"> Arizona Together </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Retail stores (Maintain physical distancing, operate with reduced occupancy and capacity based on the size of the business location with special attention to limiting areas.)<br /> 2. Personal care Barber Shops, salons, etc. (Maintain physical distancing, to the extent possible.) <br /> 3. Food and drink Restaurant dining: (Consider assigning duties to vulnerable workers that minimize their contact with customers<br /> and other employees.<br /> 4. Outdoor and recreation Pools, gyms, spas<br /> 5. Entertainment Casinos<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> As employers bring back employees from temporary layoffs and furloughs, employers should evaluate return to work considerations and procedures, including:<br /> <br /> 1. Deciding which employees to recall. Employers that are not returning all employees may find it useful to develop a thorough selection process, preferably utilizing objective criteria and train decision-makers.<br /> 2. Analyzing pay, leave, and benefits issues. Applicable leave and disability laws such as the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) and Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) may have been triggered during the time employees have spent away from the workplace. It is possible that employees will need to be reclassified under the Fair Labor Standards Act.<br /> 3. Implementing new safety protocols. This may be a good time to evaluate whether the company continues meet to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's general standards and any increased recommendations for mitigating the spread of COVID-19.<br /> 4. Managing refusals to return to work. Are employees refusing to return to work out of fear of COVID-19, to continue collecting unemployment insurance benefits, or because of a disability? It is important to consider intersecting and overlapping laws, if applicable, including paid sick leave, FMLA, and ADA, among others.<br /> 5. Maintaining privacy. Employers may want to review, and update as needed, policies on maintaining the privacy of employee medical information as well as steps to keep COVID-19 screening data private.<br /> 6. Maintaining positive employee relations. Employers may want to consider training supervisors, encouraging open-door communication, and conducting opinion surveys.<br /> 7. Prioritizing diversity, equity, and inclusion. COVID-19 presents an opportunity to either create or build upon diversity and inclusion initiatives that are designed to increase employee morale and engagement. Employers may want to consider the importance of employee-facing programs to continue to support employees through these challenging times, especially with the childcare issues caused by widespread school closures and other issues.<br /> 8. Conducting drug testing and background checks. If employees were laid off instead of furloughed, employers may want to consider whether new drug tests and background checks need to be administered.<br /> <br /> In addition to these general considerations, employers may want to evaluate any federal, state, county, or local requirements or recommendations that may reduce the further spread of COVID-19, especially as employees return to the workplace. Among these are the following:<br /> <br /> 1. Assessing distancing in cubicle and multi-user work and rest areas;<br /> 2. Reviewing wall/cubicle heights, especially for employees who do not have private offices;<br /> 3. Encouraging social/physical distancing in break rooms or consider limiting their usage;<br /> 4. Considering discontinuing the usage of common devices, including but not limited to microwaves, staplers, and copiers or implementing ways to enhance cleaning of those shared tools;<br /> Providing adequate personal protective equipment;<br /> 5. Requiring or permitting employees to use face coverings in accordance with recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and other public health authorities;<br /> 6. Conducting temperature scans or self-checks prior to employees entering the workplace and carefully evaluating all issues surrounding those checks, such as compensability and physical distancing while waiting for such screening;<br /> 7. Closing conference rooms that do not permit physical/social distancing and implementing policies for cleaning conference rooms, as well as communicating those processes and protections to employees;<br /> 8. Implementing policies or procedures for employees who are screened at the beginning of the day but leave the premises for breaks, lunch, or meetings;<br /> 9. Determining whether continued screening of visitors is necessary and how to lawfully conduct them based on the business realities present;<br /> 10. Considering rotational office visits (e.g., shifts) to minimize the number of employees physically present in the workplace at a single time; and<br /> 11. Conducting training prior to employees returning to work to establish the new "normal" and establishing new requirements to minimize the spread of the virus (e.g., no handshakes or handshake alternatives). </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> 1. Stay home if sick.<br /> 2. Implement symptom screening for employees prior to the start of shifts in high risk industries. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> 1. Provide and require employees to wear masks when possible. <br /> 2. Considering offering cloth face coverings to visitors to wear. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> 1. Stay at least 6 feet away from others while shopping and in lines.<br /> 2. Operate with reduced occupancy and capacity based on the size of the business location with special attention to limiting areas where customers and employees can congregate.<br /> 3. Close fitting rooms at clothing stores, meeting rooms or other enclosed spaces accessible to customers that do not allow for appropriate physical distancing. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> 1. Provide access to soap and water for handwashing or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer at stations around the store, salon or spa for use by employees and clients. Require employees to wash hands immediately before and after providing client service. <br /> 2. Wash your hands with soap and water or use hand sanitizer, especially after touching frequently used items or surfaces.<br /> 3. Avoid touching your face.<br /> 4. Sneeze or cough into a tissue, or the inside of your elbow.<br /> 5. Disinfect frequently used items and surfaces as much as possible.<br /> 6. Strongly consider using face coverings while in public, and particularly when using mass transit. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> 1. Implement comprehensive sanitation protocols.<br /> 2. Intensify cleaning, disinfection, and ventilation practices. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Contact tracers also educate individuals on the need to monitor themselves for symptoms of COVID-19, and they request permission to enroll the COVID-19-positive person in the SARA (Situational Awareness Response Assistant) Alert system. If staff have been tested for COVID-19 and are awaiting results, they should remain under home isolation precautions.<br /> 2. If staff have tested positive for COVID-19, they should remain under home isolation precautions for 7 days from specimen collection OR until 72 hours after fever is gone and symptoms of acute infection resolve, whichever is longer.<br /> 3. If staff have tested negative for COVID-19 and have compatible symptoms (fever, cough, shortness of breath), they should stay home from others until 72 hours after all symptoms of acute infection resolve.<br /> 4. If staff have fever with cough or shortness of breath and have not been tested for COVID-19, they should stay home away from others until 72 hours after fever is gone and symptoms of acute infection resolve.<br /> 5. If staff have other non-compatible symptoms and have not been tested for COVID-19, they should stay home until 24 hours after all symptoms are gone without the use of medicine.<br /> 6. At this time, a healthcare provider's note for employees who are sick with acute respiratory illness should not be required to validate their illness or to return to work, as healthcare provider offices and medical facilities may be extremely busy and not able to provide such documentation in a timely way.<br /> 7. Please contact the Arizona COVID-19 Hotline (1-844-542-8201) if you have questions.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Critical procedures will be prioritized due to surgery backlog. Beginning April 22, all non-essential or elective surgeries, including elective dental surgeries, that use PPE or ventilators can be performed as of May 1 if they can prove implemented measures of PPE, adequate staffing and bed capacity & testing of staff and patients.<br /> <br /> Starting May 1, hospitals and outpatient surgical centers are resuming elective surgeries, with assurances that these facilities have adequate supplies and PPE. To date, over 1,090 facilities and counting are eligible to resume elective surgeries. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Ordered closed for the academic year </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.natlawreview.com/article/covid-19-and-arizona-paid-sick-leave-law-us"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-08 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://azgovernor.gov/governor/reopening-guidance"> Arizona Department of Health Services Guidance </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.azdhs.gov/documents/preparedness/epidemiology-disease-control/infectious-disease-epidemiology/novel-coronavirus/community/visitor-screening-protocol.pdf"> Screening for Visitors and Staff </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.azdhs.gov/documents/preparedness/epidemiology-disease-control/infectious-disease-epidemiology/novel-coronavirus/eo-2020-34.pdf"> Executive Order 2020-34 </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Arkansas')" data-value="5" class="collapsible">Arkansas</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> No stay at home order </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/novel-coronavirus" target="_blank"> Ongoing Health Directives and Orders </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right">N/A</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now: <br /> 1. Outdoor and recreation Campgrounds (Mitigate risks of contracting or spreading COVID-19)<br /> 2. Gyms; Pools<br /> 3. Personal care Hair salons, barbershops, nail salons etc.<br /> 4. Food and drink Restaurant dining; Bars (Open with restrictions)<br /> 5. Entertainment Theaters, stadiums, museums, bowling alleys; Casinos (Maintain social distancing requirements) </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Please visit https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/covid-19-health-guidances for industry specific details. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Employers should screen employees for fever, cough, shortness of breath, sore throat, or loss of taste or smell as they are entering the building at the beginning work. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> Restaurants only: <br /> 1. All staff who come in contact with patrons must wear a face mask that completely covers their nose and mouth. Staff in the back are encouraged to wear a face mask<br /> 2. All staff are required to wear gloves. Gloves shall be changed out between each customer, customer group, or task.<br /> 3. Patrons must wear a face covering upon entrance and while in the restaurant until the food or drink is served.<br /> 4. Service may be declined to patrons not wearing masks. <br /> <br /> Please visit https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/covid-19-health-guidances for industry specific details. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> Restaurants only: <br /> 1. Dine-in service may resume; however, seating shall be limited up to 33% of total seating capacity. This includes indoor and outdoor dining areas. <br /> 2. Seating shall be adjusted to maintain 10-foot physical distancing between tables so occupied seats are six feet from seats at adjacent tables. <br /> 3. Groups shall be limited, not to exceed 10 people.<br /> <br /> Please visit https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/covid-19-health-guidances for industry specific details. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> 1. Monitoring of frequent handwashing and no bare-hand contact of ready-to-eat foods by staff.<br /> 2. Actively encourage sick employees to stay home<br /> 3. Separate sick employees<br /> 4. Emphasize staying home when sick, respiratory etiquette and hand hygiene by all employees<br /> 5. Perform routine environmental cleaning<br /> 6. Advise employees before traveling to take certain steps<br /> 7. Please visit https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/covid-19-health-guidances for industry specific details. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> 1. Actively encourage sick employees to stay home<br /> 2. Separate sick employees<br /> 3. Emphasize staying home when sick, respiratory etiquette and hand hygiene by all employees<br /> 4. Perform routine environmental cleaning<br /> 5. Advise employees before traveling to take certain steps<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> 1. Employees Being Monitored Due to Possible Exposure<br /> 2. If any of your employees are being monitored due to their possible exposure to coronavirus disease 2019, also referred to as COVID-19, they will be placed under home self-quarantine by the Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) for 14 days after leaving an area of concern. The areas of concern include any country with a Level 2 or higher travel advisory. If this occurs, ADH will provide the person with a letter, and they have the option of requesting a letter be provided to you as well. This letter provides additional information regarding the quarantine, including the date the employee can return to work.<br /> 3. During this time, the person is expected to stay home during the entire 14-day period and not leave for any reason, except to seek any needed medical care.<br /> 4. If the employee does not develop symptoms of COVID-19 prior to the end of the self-quarantine period, they will be free to resume normal activities, including school or work. They will also receive a letter stating they have completed the home quarantine period.<br /> 5. Please call the ADH at 1-800-803-7847 if you have any questions.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> ] </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Ordered closed for the academic year </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.arkansasstatechamber.com/news-publications/news-releases/employers-and-coronavirus/"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-15 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/business_limitations_directive.pdf"> Directives for Business Limitations </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/PoultryFederationIndustryCOVID3.31.20.pdf"> Guidance for Businesses </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/covid-19-guidance-for-employers"> For Employers </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on California')" data-value="6" class="collapsible">California</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Regional reopening in progress </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://covid19.ca.gov/stay-home-except-for-essential-needs/" target="_blank"> Stay At Home Executive Order </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap/" target="_blank"> Roadmap to Resilience </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> 1. Retail (Operate with a 50% capacity and maintain six-foot distancing<br /> 2. Place of Worship (Operate with a 25% capacity or a maximum of 100 attendees, whichever is lower)<br /> 3. Industry Offices (Maintain social distancing to the maximum extent possible)<br /> 4. Outdoor museums (Limit visitor group size to six or fewer. People from the same household do<br /> not need to be six feet apart.)<br /> 5. Restaurants (Limited seating capacity) </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Before reopening all facilities must:<br /> 1. Perform a detailed risk assessment and implement a site-specific protection plan.<br /> 2. Train employees on how to limit the spread of COVID-19, including how to screen themselves for symptoms and stay home if they have them.<br /> 3. Implement individual control measures and screenings.<br /> 4. Implement disinfecting protocols.<br /> 7. Implement physical distancing guidelines.<br /> 8. The following are links to guidance and checklists (if available) by industry<br /> <br /> Industry specific guidance can be found in two places. Guidance for industries open in all counties can be found here: https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance/ and guidance for industries open in counties further ahead in the resilience roadmap can be found here (this applies to most counties): https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap-counties/. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> Before reopening, all facilities must: <br /> 1. Train employees on how to limit the spread of COVID-19. This includes how to screen themselves for symptoms at home and when to stay home.<br /> 2. Set up individual control measures and screenings<br /> 3. Actively encourage sick employees to stay home.<br /> 4. Send employees with acute respiratory illness symptoms home immediately. <br /> <br /> For high risk industries: <br /> 1. Temperature checks and symptom screening required prior to shift. <br /> 2. See industry specific guidance here: https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance/ and guidance for further industries here: https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap-counties/ </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> All facilities:<br /> 1. Must perform a detailed risk assessment and create a site-specific protection plan. <br /> 2. Recommended use of facial coverings for employees . Proper use of face coverings, includes that face coverings must cover the nose and mouth, employees should wash or sanitize hands before and after using or adjusting face coverings, employees should avoid touching the eyes, nose, and mouth, and face coverings should be washed or discarded after each shift. <br /> 3. Ensure temporary and contract workers at the facility are also properly trained in COVID-19 prevention policies and have necessary supplies and PPE. Discuss these responsibilities ahead of time with organizations<br /> supplying temporary and/or contract workers.<br /> <br /> High risk industries may require further protections. See here: https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance/ and here: https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap-counties/ for guidance by industry. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> All facilities: <br /> 1. Allow flexible worksites, telecommuting and flexible work hours to increase physical distance among employees<br /> 2. Use other methods of minimizing exposure between employees, and between employees and the public<br /> 3. Follow general Strongly Suggested Details as per CDC<br /> 3a. Avoid close contact with people who are sick, even inside your home. If possible, maintain 6 feet between the person who is sick and other household members.<br /> 3b. Put distance between yourself and other people outside of your home.<br /> 3c. Remember that some people without symptoms may be able to spread virus.<br /> 3d. Stay at least 6 feet (about 2 arms' length) from other people.<br /> 3e. Do not gather in groups.<br /> 3f. Stay out of crowded places and avoid mass gatherings.<br /> 3g. Keeping distance from others is especially important for people who are at higher risk of getting very sick.<br /> <br /> High risk industries may require further protections. See here: https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance/ and here: https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap-counties/ for guidance by industry. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> All facilities must provide information and training to employees on:<br /> 1. Cough and sneeze etiquette<br /> 2. Hand hygiene<br /> 3. Avoiding close contact with sick persons<br /> 4. Avoiding touching eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands<br /> 5. Avoiding sharing personal items with co-workers (i.e. dishes, cups, utensils, towels)<br /> 6. Providing tissues, no-touch disposal trash cans and hand sanitizer for use by employees<br /> <br /> High risk industries may require further protections. See here: https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance/ and here: https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap-counties/ for guidance by industry. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Industry Specific</strong><br> All facilities: <br /> 2. Use the cleaning agents that are usually used in these areas, and follow the directions on the label.<br /> 3. Provide disposable wipes so that commonly used surfaces (for example, doorknobs, keyboards, remote controls, desks, grocery carts, etc.) can be wiped down by employees before each use, and by customers, if possible.<br /> 4. Eliminate or regularly sanitize any items in common spaces (i.e., break rooms) that are shared between individuals (i.e., condiments, coffee makers, vending machines).<br /> <br /> High risk industries may require further protections. See here: https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance/ and here: https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap-counties/ for guidance by industry. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> All facilities: <br /> 1. Establish a written, worksite-specific COVID-19 prevention plan at every facility, perform a comprehensive risk assessment of all work areas, and designate a person at each facility to implement the plan.<br /> 2. Identify contact information for the local health department where the facility is located, for communicating information about COVID-19 outbreaks among employees.<br /> 3. Identify close contacts (within six feet for 15 minutes or more) of an infected employee and take steps to isolate COVID-19 positive employee(s) and close contacts. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Hospitals can resume providing some elective surgeries.These will only be surgeries that are "foundational to people's health," such as heart valve replacements or tumor removals, and will not include surgeries deemed to be solely cosmetic.<br /> <br /> What you should know:<br /> <br /> 1. The facilities can restart procedures because hospitalizations for COVID-19 patients have been lower than expected, personal protective equipment shortages have resolved in the region, and the facilities have the testing capacity to prescreen all patients.<br /> 2. The procedures could be delayed if the facilities experience a surge of COVID-19 patients.<br /> 3. Sansum Clinic plans to restart procedures at half capacity starting in early May. Sansum formed a committee with surgeons, the surgery center's medical director, anesthesiologists and administrative staff to determine how to best proceed. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Recommended closed for the academic year </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.dir.ca.gov/dlse/2019-Novel-Coronavirus.htm?_sm_au_=iVVD4Tb5ZJSRJRLqJ8MfKK7vWLCsW"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> California, Washington, Nevada and Oregon will form a joint task force to plan for reopening </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-08 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance/"> Statewide industry guidance to reduce risk </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Colorado')" data-value="7" class="collapsible">Colorado</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home order expired - Reopening in progress </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20044%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf" target="_blank"> Safer at Home Executive Order </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://covid19.colorado.gov/safer-at-home" target="_blank"> Colorado Safer at Home </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Personal care Salons and personal services (Appointments only, no more than 10 people inside, and maintain social distancing)<br /> 2. Retail stores (Operate with 50% capacity)<br /> 3. Industries Offices; Manufacturing (Operate with 50% capacity)<br /> 4. Outdoor and recreation Campgrounds (Operate with 50% capacity or up to 50 people whichever is fewer and maintain six-foot distancing)<br /> 5. Food and drink Restaurants dining (Maintain six-foot distancing,<br /> 6. Houses of Worship (Operate with 50% capacity) </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> 1. Provide flexible or remote scheduling for employees who need to continue to observe Stay-at-Home, who may have child or elder care obligations, or who live with a person who still needs to observe Stay-at-Home due to underlying condition, age, or other factors. <br /> 2. Businesses should deputize workplace coordinator(s) charged with addressing COVID-19 issues.<br /> 3. Large businesses and factories are encouraged to do temperature checks of their employees.<br /> 4. Employees should still stay at least 6 feet from one another, wear masks and wash their hands frequently. <br /> 5. Offices should also also designate a coronavirus coordinator to make sure workers' temperatures are taken regularly, high-touch surfaces are sanitized, windows stay open if possible. <br /> 6. Avoid gatherings of more than 10 people<br /> 7. Businesses should encourage telecommuting to the maximum extent possible. Businesses that need an in-person workforce may do so at 50% capacity, with social distancing and mask wearing.<br /> 8. Maintaining a sustainable level of social distancing by the general public.<br /> 9. Maintaining a sustainable level of social distancing by the general public plus advise older adults (age>60) to maintain high levels of social distancing.<br /> 10. Maintaining a sustainable level of social distancing and promote mask wearing by the public. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Require employees showing any symptoms or signs of sickness, or who has been in contact with known positive cases to stay home.<br /> 2. Implement symptom monitoring protocols (including workplace temperature monitoring and symptom screening questions) where possible<br /> <br /> Best Practices: <br /> 1. Best practice is to implement a temperature check station and at-the-door symptom screening at the entrance to the business. If this is not feasible, employee will check for symptoms at home and report symptoms either electronically or on paper per the system created by the business. <br /> 2. Temperature Screening Guidelines: Temperature of 100.4 is automatic "No GO." The person should be politely asked to exit the building immediately and instructed to call their supervisor for notification. Temperature of 99.2 or higher, but less than 100, have the person begin monitoring their temperature twice a day for a minimum of 7 days to determine if the temperature is going up or down. The person should notify their supervisor. <br /> Place the "Color of the day" wristband on person's wrist and proceed to data entry. <br /> 3. Data Entry Screening Guidelines: Data entry personnel will use the Employee Screening Form to capture information electronically. If the computer is not accessible, use the manual paper form and complete data entry at a later time. If the person answers affirmative to a combination of two of any of the following, the person should be politely asked to leave immediately and notify their supervisor. Nasal congestion may be due to many factors during this time of year. If nasal congestion is present, mark the box and ask the person to self-monitor for additional symptoms. Complete data entry and allow the person to proceed. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Provide appropriate protective gear like gloves, masks, and face coverings and encourage appropriate use. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Maintain 6-foot distancing when possible, and discourage shared spaces.<br /> 2. Avoid gatherings (meetings, waiting rooms, etc) of more than 10 people.<br /> 3. Phase shifts and breaks to reduce employee density.<br /> 4. Encourage and enable remote work whenever possible. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Provide hand washing facilities/stations and hand sanitizer.<br /> 2. Encourage breaks to wash hands or use hand sanitizer.<br /> 3. Post signage for employees and customers on good hygiene. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Eliminate or regularly disinfect any items in common spaces (i.e., break rooms) that are shared between individuals, e.g.,, condiments, coffee makers, vending machines).<br /> 2. Establish policies and procedures for routine and targeted cleaning of environmental surfaces as indicated by the level of patient contact and degree of soiling. (II)<br /> 3. Clean and disinfect surfaces that are likely to be contaminated with pathogens, including those that are in close proximity to the patient (e.g., bed rails, over bed tables) and frequently-touched surfaces in the patient care environment (e.g., door knobs, surfaces in and surrounding toilets in patients' rooms) on a more frequent schedule compared to that for other surfaces (e.g., horizontal surfaces in waiting rooms) (IB)<br /> 4. Use EPA-registered disinfectants that have microbicidal (i.e., killing) activity against the pathogens most likely to contaminate the patient-care environment. Use in accordance with manufacturer's instructions (IB/IC)<br /> 5. Include multi-use electronic equipment in policies and procedures for preventing contamination and for cleaning and disinfection, especially those items that are used by patients, those used during delivery of patient care, and mobile devices that are moved in and out of patient rooms frequently (e.g., daily) (IB)<br /> 6. No recommendation for use of removable protective covers or washable keyboards. (Unresolved issue) https://drive.google.com/file/d/1pXAFPXCTLqBZvTJpuqrH45YeLB_Jc2wP/view<br /> <br /> These recommendations provide supplemental information to the general cleaning and disinfecting recommendations already provided by the Department and are consistent with US FDA. It is important to note that labeled instructions must be followed on all sanitizing and disinfecting products, sanitizers must be EPA registered and disinfectants must be EPA registered and hospital-grade (effective against Salmonella choleraesuis (enteric), Staphylococcus aureus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa). </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Employees who have been in close contact with an exposed or symptomatic person (within 6 feet for at least 10 minutes) should not report to work and should self-quarantine.<br /> 2. Separates people and restricts their movement if they were exposed to a contagious disease to see if they become sick. This could include exposure to a person who has tested positive for COVID-19 or a person with the symptoms of COVID-19. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Medical, dental, or veterinary voluntary or elective surgeries or procedures may resume as long as the facility, office, surgical center, hospital, or other setting (Facilities or Facility) follows protocols and criteria set forth in this Executive order and any accompanying Public Health Order (PHO) issued by CDPHE. A voluntary or elective surgery or procedure means that the surgery or procedure can be delayed for a minimum of three months without undue risk to the current </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Ordered closed for the academic year </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.colorado.gov/pacific/cdle/colorado-health-emergency-leave-pay-%E2%80%9Ccolorado-help%E2%80%9D-rules"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-15 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rLNy2vAgVvebgqfwBpJGlPph6lzIPBrM/view"> Full guidelines </a><a target="_blank" href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/107dLRAJaD4ZtNJGy8geSf0UvngesvKYd/view"> Workplace Guideance </a><a target="_blank" href="https://covid19.colorado.gov/safer-at-home/safer-at-home-office-based-business"> Office-Based Businesses </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Connecticut')" data-value="8" class="collapsible">Connecticut</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home order expired - Reopening in progress </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7PP.pdf" target="_blank"> Executive Order No.7PP </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://portal.ct.gov/coronavirus" target="_blank"> Connecticut Reopening Details </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now: <br /> 1. Personal care Salons and personal services (Maintain six-foot social distance and tools must be disinfected between customer and operate with 50% capacity)<br /> 2. Retail stores (Operate with 50% capacity)<br /> 3. Industries Offices; Manufacturing 9<br /> 4. Outdoor (Operate with 50% capacity)<br /> 5. Recreation Campgrounds (Public areas will be closed and maintain 20 feet between each campsite)<br /> 6. Food and drink Restaurants dining (Operate with 50% capacity)<br /> 7. Hotels (Operate with 50% capacity)<br /> 8. Amusement Parks (Calculated safe maximum occupancy with a 50% capacity rate and maintain social distancing guidelines) </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Businesses began to open May 20th, with strict controls on business operations and societal interaction. This includes, among other measures:<br /> 1. Capacity limit of 50% for businesses that reopen.<br /> 2. Strict cleaning and disinfection protocols in all settings.<br /> 3. Those who can work from home should continue to do so.<br /> 4. Those in high-risk groups (comorbidities) and over the age of 65 should continue to stay safe and stay home.<br /> 5. Facemasks should continue to be worn in public at all times.<br /> 6. Social gatherings will be restricted to a maximum of 5 people. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> Ask employees resuming on-premise work to confirm they have not experienced COVID-19 CDC-defined symptoms and to monitor their own symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath, or any two of the following symptoms: (Sick employees should be directed to stay home)<br /> 1. Fever <br /> 2. Chills <br /> 3. Repeated shaking with chills <br /> 4. Muscle pain <br /> 5. Headache <br /> 6. Sore throat <br /> 7. New loss of taste or smell. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> Consistent with Governor Ned Lamont's previous order for essential businesses, employers must provide a face mask or other face covering for employees to wear at work, unless doing so would be contrary to an employee's health or safety due to medical conditions. (Customers are expected to do the same.) Subject to that exception, the mask must be utilized when the employee is working in a non-segregated space. Gloves and eye protection must be provided to employees working with cleaning chemicals. If employers expect to reopen, the guidance recommends that they begin estimating the necessary amounts of masks, gloves, and eye protection (PPE) needed, and begin procuring it. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Enforce rules on maximum gathering size of 5 people.<br /> 2. Limit maximum occupancy to 50% of usual occupancy in any indoor space.<br /> 3. Install visual social distancing markers to encourage employees and customers to remain 6 ft apart in common spaces: By placing markers along the queue for washrooms and by marking as "out of service" any seating that does not fit the social distancing rules.<br /> 4. Rearrange space to maintain at least 6 feet of distance between customers when they may be seated (e.g., ensure tables are at least 6+ ft apart. This may require keeping some booths or seats empty. Distance shall be measured from the closest chair at one table to the closest chair at another table). <br /> 5. Ensure employees do not share equipment to the extent possible. If shared, clean after each use. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Hand sanitizer shall be made available at entrance points and common areas, where possible.<br /> 2. Ensure employees wash their hands routinely using soap and water for at least 20 seconds.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Cleaning, disinfectant products, and/or disposable disinfectant wipes should be made available near commonly used surfaces, where possible, like: <br /> 1a. High-transit surfaces (e.g., door handles) <br /> 1b. Check-out counters<br /> 2. Clean and disinfect bathrooms frequently, implement use of cleaning log for tracking. Clean multiple times a day and hourly during busy times.<br /> 3. Follow federal guidelines (CDC, EPA) on what specific products should be used and how.<br /> 4. Use products that meet EPA's criteria for use against SARS-CoV-2 and that are appropriate for the surface. Disinfectants are irritants and sensitizers and should be used cautiously. <br /> 5. Prior to wiping the surface, allow the disinfectant to sit for the necessary contact time recommended by the manufacturer. Train staff on proper cleaning procedures to ensure safe and correct application of disinfectants.<br /> 6. Avoid all food contact surfaces when using disinfectants, these surfaces should be sanitized instead.<br /> 7. Clean and disinfect common areas, high transit areas, and frequently touched surfaces on an ongoing basis (at least daily) and more frequently if used more often. Clean and disinfect shared objects after each use, including elevators, panels and buttons, door handles, etc. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> In the event of a confirmed case employees shall inform their employers and follow state testing and contact tracing protocols. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right">
