This guidance is not intended to replace any existing applicable local, state, and federal laws, regulations, and standards.<br /> <br /> <br /> The following are minimum guidelines that apply to office-based work. Some workplaces, dependent on industry, risk level, and phase may have stricter regulations. Please visit the business reopening link for more information, https://forward.ny.gov/.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. An employee who screens positive for COVID-19 symptoms should not be allowed to enter the location and should be sent home with instructions to contact their healthcare provider for assessment and testing. 2. Immediately notify state and local health departments of confirmed positive cases and provide the individual with information on healthcare and testing resources
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Implement mandatory health screening practices (e.g. questionnaire, temperature check) for employees asking about (1) COVID-19 symptoms in past 14 days, (2) positive COVID-19 test in past 14 days, and/or (3) close or proximate contact with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 case in past 14 days. <br /> 2. Employees who are sick should stay home or return to home, if they become ill at work.<br /> 3. An employee who screens positive for COVID-19 symptoms should not be allowed to enter the location and should be sent home with instructions to contact their healthcare provider for assessment and testing.<br /> 4. Review all responses collected by the screening process on a daily basis and maintain a record of such review. Identify a contact as the party for individuals to inform if they later are experiencing COVID-19-related symptoms, as noted in the questionnaire.<br /> 5. Coordinate with building managers to facilitate screening. Tenants are responsible for screening their own employees and visitors, unless tenants and building management have agreed to alternate arrangement to ensure screening is in effect.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Provide workers with an acceptable face covering at no cost to the employees/contractors and have an adequate supply of coverings in case of need for replacement. <br /> 2. Acceptable face coverings include but are not limited to cloth (e.g. homemade sewn, quick cut, bandana), surgical masks, and face shields. <br /> 3. Clean, replace, and prohibit sharing of face coverings. Consult the CDC guidance for additional information on cloth face coverings and other types of personal protective equipment (PPE), as well as instructions on use and cleaning and disinfection. <br /> 4. Train workers on how to don, doff, clean and disinfect (as applicable), and discard PPE (training should be extended to contractors if the building managers/owners supply contractors with PPE). <br /> 5. Must advise workers and visitors to wear face coverings in common areas including elevators, lobbies, and when traveling around the office<br /> 6. Limit the sharing of objects, such as tools, laptops, notebooks, telephones, touchscreens, and writing utensils, as well as the touching of shared surfaces; or, require workers to wear gloves when in contact with shared objects or frequently touched surfaces; or, require workers to perform hand hygiene before and after contact.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. A distance of at least 6 ft. must be maintained amongst all individuals at all times, unless safety of the core activity requires a shorter distance. <br /> 2. Any time workers or visitors must come within 6 ft. of another person, acceptable face coverings must be worn (ensuring that mouth and nose are covered). Individuals must be prepared to don a face covering if another person unexpectedly comes within 6 ft. <br /> 3. Prohibit the use of tightly small spaces (e.g. elevators, vehicles) by more than one individual at time, unless all individuals are wearing face coverings. If occupied by more than one person, keep occupancy under 50% of maximum capacity. <br /> 4. Shared workstations (e.g. hot-desks) must be cleaned and disinfected between users. <br /> 5. Reduce interpersonal contact and congregation through various methods (e.g. adjusting workplace hours, limiting in-person presence to necessary staff, shifting design, reducing on-site workforce, staggering arrival/departure times to reduce congestion in lobbies/elevators).<br /> 6. Non-essential common areas (e.g. gyms, pools, game rooms) must remain closed.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Provide and maintain hand hygiene stations in office, including handwashing with soap, running warm water, and disposable paper towels, lined garbage can, as well as an alcohol-based hand sanitizer containing 60% or more alcohol for areas where handwashing is not feasible. <br /> <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Adhere to hygiene, cleaning, and disinfection requirements from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and Department of Health (DOH) and maintain cleaning logs on site that document date, time, and scope of cleaning.<br /> 2. Regularly clean and disinfect the site and more frequently clean and disinfect high risk areas used by many individuals and for frequently touched surfaces. <br /> 3. Rigorous cleaning and disinfection must occur at least after each shift, daily, or more frequently as needed. <br /> 4. Provide cleaning and disinfection of exposed areas in the event that an individual is confirmed to have COVID19, with such cleaning and disinfection to include, at a minimum, all heavy transit areas and high-touch surfaces (e.g. elevators, lobbies, building entrances, badge scanners, restrooms handrails, door handles). <br /> 5. Ensure that equipment is regularly cleaned and disinfected, including at least as often as employees and contractors change workstations, using Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) products identified by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as effective against COVID-19.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Employees who are sick should stay home or return to home, if they become ill at work.<br /> 2. Identify a point-of-contact as the party for workers and visitors to inform if they later are experiencing COVID19-related symptoms, as noted in the questionnaire.<br /> 3. Immediately notify state and local health departments of confirmed positive cases and provide the individual with information on healthcare and testing resources.<br /> 4. Provide cleaning and disinfection of exposed areas in the event that an individual is confirmed to have COVID19, with such cleaning and disinfection to include, at a minimum, all heavy transit areas and high-touch surfaces (e.g. elevators, lobbies, building entrances, badge scanners, restrooms handrails, door handles). <br /> <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Elective Surgeries can resume </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Plan to reopen in Fall </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://paidfamilyleave.ny.gov/COVID19"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Massachusetts and Delaware will form a joint task force to plan for reopening the economy </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-17 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://forward.ny.gov/industries-reopening-phase"> Reopening in Phases </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/OfficesSummaryGuidelines.pdf"> Office Based Work Guidelines </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on North Carolina')" data-value="36" class="collapsible">North Carolina</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home order expired - Reopening in progress </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO141-Phase-2.pdf" target="_blank"> Executive Order 141 </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/NC-3-PHASE-PLAN.pdf" target="_blank"> Staying Ahead of the Curve </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now (Phase 2 - lasting 5 weeks):<br /> 1. Retail (Retail stores - no more than 50% of the stated fire capacity or 12 per 1,000 square feet if there is not a fire code number readily available)<br /> 2. Food and drink (Restaurant dining - 50% of maximum occupancy will be allowed inside the building, or 12 people per 1,000 feet if the restaurant does not have a fire code number)<br /> 3. Personal care (Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors - no more than 50% of the stated fire capacity or 12 per 1,000 square feet if there is not a fire code number readily available)<br /> 4. Outdoor and recreation Pools (50% capacity)<br /> 5. Childcare facilities<br /> <br /> Remain closed:<br /> 1. Bars<br /> 2. Nightclubs<br /> 3. Gyms and Fitness studios <br /> 4. Health clubs <br /> 5. Museums </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Starting at 5pm on Friday May 22, 2020, North Carolina will begin Phase 2 which allows certain businesses and organizations to open or remain open. Those businesses and organizations should follow the guidelines below to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Guidelines for Conducting Business: Any scenario in which many people gather together poses a risk for COVID-19 transmission. All businesses and organizations where groups of people gather in an enclosed space should create and implement a plan to minimize the opportunity for COVID-19 transmission at their facility. The general guidance below will help businesses and organizations reduce the spread of COVID-19 in their communities. Specific guidance for retail and other public facing businesses can be found on the NC DHHS COVID-19 response site.<br /> <br /> 1. Social distancing (physical distancing) means keeping space between yourself and other people outside of your home. Stay at least 6 feet (about 2 arms length) from other people; do not gather in groups; stay out of crowded places and avoid mass gatherings. Phase 2 includes several requirements and recommendations to support social distancing in spaces where the public may gather.<br /> 2. It is strongly recommended that all individuals wear a cloth face covering when they may be near (less than 6 feet from) other people. <br /> 3. Washing hands with soap for 20 seconds or using hand sanitizer reduces the spread of transmission. <br /> 4. Conducting regular screening for symptoms can help reduce exposure. Staff should be encouraged to self-monitor for symptoms such as fever, cough, or shortness of breath. <br /> <br /> The following are minimum guidelines that apply to all businesses. Some workplaces, dependent on industry and risk level, may have stricter regulations. Please visit the link for more information, https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/guidance#businesses. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Employees who have symptoms when they arrive at work or become sick during the day should immediately be separated from other employees, customers, and visitors and sent home. <br /> 2. Conduct daily symptom screening (use this standard interview questionnaire) (English|Spanish) of employees at entrance to workplace with immediately sending symptomatic workers home to isolate. <br /> 3. Post signage at the main entrance requesting that people who have been symptomatic with fever and/or cough not enter, such as Know Your Ws/Stop if You Have Symptoms flyers (English - Color, Black & White; Spanish - Color, Black & White). <br /> 4. Have a plan in place for immediately removing employee from work if symptoms develop. <br /> 5. Establish and enforce sick leave policies to prevent the spread of disease, including: o Enforcing employees staying home if sick. o Encouraging liberal use of sick leave policy. o Expanding paid leave policies to allow employees to stay home when sick. <br /> 6. Per CDC guidelines, if an employee has been diagnosed with COVID-19 or is presumed positive by a medical professional due to symptoms, the employee should be excluded from work until: o No fever for at least 72 hours since recovery (without the use of fever-reducing medicine) AND o Other symptoms have improved (e.g., coughing, shortness of breath) AND o At least 10 days have passed since first symptoms <br /> 7. Per CDC guidelines, if an employee has been diagnosed with COVID-19 but does not have symptoms, they should remain out of work until 10 days have passed since the date of their first positive COVID-19 diagnostic test, assuming they have not subsequently developed symptoms since their positive test. <br /> 8. Require symptomatic employees to wear masks until leaving the office. Cleaning and disinfecting procedure should be implemented by designated personnel following CDC guidelines once sick employee leaves. <br /> 9. Provide employees with information on help lines to access information or other support in reference to COVID-19, e.g. 211 and Hope4NC Helpline (1-855-587-3463).<br /> <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. It is encouraged that businesses and organizations provide cloth face coverings for employees and customers. If provided, they must be single use or properly laundered using hot water and a high heat dryer between uses.<br /> 2. Please share guidance to employees on use, wearing, and removal of cloth face coverings, such as CDCs guidance on wearing and removing cloth face masks, CDCs use of cloth face coverings, and CDCs cloth face coverings FAQs.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Limit in-person meetings to no more than 10 people. <br /> 2. Allow staff to work remotely as much as possible.<br /> 3. Stagger shifts when remote working is not possible. <br /> 4. Post signage around the office reminding staff about social distancing (staying at least 6 feet away from others). Know Your Ws sign templates are available in English and Spanish on the NC DHHS COVID-19 response site. <br /> 5. Consider posting signs around frequently touched objects like shared printers or bathroom sinks. Move desks and workstations at least six (6) feet apart. <br /> 6. Mark six (6) feet of spacing on the floor in higher traffic areas, such as reception areas. <br /> 7. Consider closing off areas where people are more likely to gather, like breakrooms. <br /> 8. Clearly mark designated entry and exit points; if a building has only one entry/exit point, try to stagger entry and exit times if possible. <br /> 9. Develop and use systems that allow for online, email, or telephone transactions. <br /> 10. Provide or encourage staff to bring their own water or individual meals, to reduce possible exposure. <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Promote frequent use of hand washing and hand sanitizer for staff and individuals. Require handwashing of staff immediately upon reporting to work, after contact with individuals, after performing cleaning and disinfecting activities, and frequently throughout the day. <br /> 2. Provide, whenever available, hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol) at the entrance and other areas. Systematically and frequently check and refill hand sanitizers and assure soap and hand drying materials are available at all sinks. <br /> 3. Provide tissues for proper cough and sneeze hygiene.<br /> <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Perform ongoing and routine environmental cleaning and disinfection of high-touch areas (e.g., doors, doorknobs, rails, tables, chairs) with an EPA approved disinfectant for SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19), and increase disinfection during times when the business may have more visitors. <br /> 2. Increase circulation of outdoor air as much as possible by opening windows and doors, using fans, or other methods. Do not open windows and doors if they pose a safety risk. <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Per CDC guidelines, if an employee has been diagnosed with COVID-19 or is presumed positive by a medical professional due to symptoms, the employee should be excluded from work until: o No fever for at least 72 hours since recovery (without the use of fever-reducing medicine) AND o Other symptoms have improved (e.g., coughing, shortness of breath) AND o At least 10 days have passed since first symptoms <br /> 2. Per CDC guidelines, if an employee has been diagnosed with COVID-19 but does not have symptoms, they should remain out of work until 10 days have passed since the date of their first positive COVID-19 diagnostic test, assuming they have not subsequently developed symptoms since their positive test.<br /> 3. Have a plan in place for immediately removing employee from work if symptoms develop. <br /> 4. Establish and enforce sick leave policies to prevent the spread of disease, including: o Enforcing employees staying home if sick. o Encouraging liberal use of sick leave policy. o Expanding paid leave policies to allow employees to stay home when sick.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Elective surgeries may resume </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Plan to reopen in August if data has shown improvement </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="Information Coming Soon"> Information Coming Soon </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-17 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO141-Phase-2.pdf"> Executive Order 141 </a><a target="_blank" href="https://files.nc.gov/covid/documents/guidance/Interim-Guidance-for-Businesses-and-Organizations-Phase-2.pdf"> NCDHHS Interim Guidance for Businesses </a><a target="_blank" href="https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/guidance#businesses"> Phase 2 Business Guidance </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on North Dakota')" data-value="37" class="collapsible">North Dakota</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> No stay at home order </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.7%20FINAL.pdf" target="_blank"> Executive Order 2020-06.7 </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://ndresponse.gov/covid-19-resources/covid-19-business-and-employer-resources/nd-smart-restart" target="_blank"> ND Smart Restart </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Food and drink (Restaurant dining, bars - limited to 75% of normal operating capacity)<br /> 2. Outdoor and recreation (Gyms; Sports venues)<br /> 3. Personal care (Salons, tattoo parlors, massage therapy, etc.)<br /> 4. Entertainment (Movie theaters; Music and entertainment venues) </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Post signage (state provided) at all entrances of the facility informing all employees and customers that they should: Avoid entering the facility if they have a cough or fever. Maintain a minimum six-foot distance from one another. Wash their hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Limit unnecessary contact such as hugging and shaking hands<br /> <br /> The following are minimum standards that apply to all industries. Some workplaces, dependent on industry and risk level, may have stricter regulations. Please visit the link for more information, https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Standards%20for%20all%20Industries.pdf and https://ndresponse.gov/covid-19-resources/covid-19-business-and-employer-resources/covid-19-business-and-employer-workers. <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Encourage workers to stay home if they are sick<br /> 2. Businesses may check employees body temperature as a precautionary measure for your staff. When an employee calls in sick during a pandemic, ADA-covered employers may ask the employee if s/he is experiencing symptoms related to the pandemic virus; however, information about the employees illness and medical record must remain confidential.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Encourage use of cloth face coverings to employees and contracted workers whose duties require close contact (within 6 feet for 10 minutes or more) with other employees and/or the public.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. When telecommuting is not possible, employers should consider the possibility of staggering shifts or implementing flexible working hours.<br /> 2. Discourage employees from sharing desks, offices, phones and other equipment.<br /> 3. Mark six-foot increments where lines form<br /> 4. Capacity should be limited to a percentage of normal operating capacity for controlled and managed facilities or capped at a total number. If there is no way to control access of entry (egress), spread out activities to double the normal footprint.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. When possible, install physical barriers and minimize face-to-face contact by limiting the publics access to specific areas of the business. <br /> 2. Make tissues, soap, water and disposable towels, or disinfecting hand sanitizer, available for all customers and staff.<br /> 3. Provide hand sanitizer, soap and water or effective disinfectant at or near the entrance of the facility and in other appropriate areas for use by the public and employees, and in locations where there is high frequency employee interaction with members of the public (e.g. cashiers). Keep chemicals out of reach of small children. Restrooms normally open to the public shall remain open to the public with heightened hygiene and cleaning standards..<br /> <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Provide contactless payment systems or, if not feasible, disinfect all payment portals, pens and styluses after each use.<br /> 2. Regularly disinfect other high-touch surfaces according to industry standard operating procedures in conjunction with Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) use for staff<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Develop policies and procedures for prompt identification and isolation of sick staff and customers, https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/businesses-employers.html. <br /> 2. Encourage workers to stay home if they are sick<br /> <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Reopened for procedures </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Reopened for summer programs </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://ndresponse.gov/covid-19-resources/covid-19-business-and-employer-resources/covid-19-business-and-employer-labor"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-17 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Standards%20for%20all%20Industries.pdf"> Standards for all industries </a><a target="_blank" href="https://ndresponse.gov/covid-19-resources/covid-19-business-and-employer-resources/covid-19-business-and-employer-workers"> FAQ for businesses and employers </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Ohio')" data-value="38" class="collapsible">Ohio</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Reopening in progress </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Directors-Stay-Safe-Ohio-Order.pdf" target="_blank"> Ohio's Stay Safe Order </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/responsible-restart-ohio" target="_blank"> Responsible Restart Ohio </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Industries (Manufacturing, distribution, construction; Offices)<br /> 2. Retail (Retail stores)<br /> 3. Personal care (Salons, barbershops, Day spas, etc. )(Tattoo and Body piercing parlors - Oral and nose piercings are prohibited at this time) <br /> 4. Food and drink (Dine-in restaurants and bars)<br /> 5. Swimming pools and aquatic centers (limit their capacity to help guests keep 6 feet apart)<br /> 6. Banquet halls & catering centers (Events limited to 300 guests or fewer)<br /> 7. Day care services (no more than 6 infants and toddlers in a room, and no more than 9 preschool and school-aged children in a room) <br /> 8. Gyms and fitness centers<br /> 9. Dentists<br /> 10. Veterinarians<br /> 11. Expanded elective hospital services that don't require an overnight stay<br /> <br /> Reopening soon:<br /> 1. Outdoor and recreation (Bowling alleys, miniature golf and batting cages)<br /> 2. Casinos (June 19th - capacity of no more than 50%)<br /> <br /> Advisory groups without reopening dates:<br /> 1. Travel and tourism<br /> 2. Fairs<br /> 3. Large venues<br /> 4. Sports leagues </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> 5 PROTOCOLS FOR ALL BUSINESSES:<br /> 1. Require face coverings for employees and recommend them for clients/customers at all times.<br /> <br /> 2. Conduct daily health assessments by employers and employees (self-evaluation) to determine if fit for duty.<br /> <br /> 3. Maintain good hygiene at all times hand washing, sanitizing and social distancing.<br /> <br /> 4. Clean and sanitize workplaces throughout workday and at the close of business or between shifts.<br /> <br /> 5. Limit capacity to meet social distancing guidelines.<br /> a. Establish maximum capacity.<br /> b. And, use appointment setting where possible to limit congestion. <br /> <br /> <br /> The following are minimum guidelines that apply to general office environments. Some workplaces, dependent on sector and risk level, may have stricter regulations. Please visit the links for more information on sector-specific business guidance, https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/responsible-restart-ohio/sector-specific-operating-requirements/sector-specific-operating-requirements. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>information not available</strong><br> information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Employees must perform daily symptom assessment*<br /> 2. *Per the CDC, symptoms include cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, fever, chills, muscle pain, sore throat, and new loss of taste or smell. <br /> 3. Require employees to stay home if symptomatic<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Businesses must require all employees to wear facial coverings, except for one of the following reasons: Facial coverings in the work setting are prohibited by law or regulation Facial coverings are in violation of documented industry standards Facial coverings are not advisable for health reasons Facial coverings are in violation of the businesss documented safety policies Facial coverings are not required when the employee works alone in an assigned work area There is a functional (practical) reason for an employee not to wear a facial covering in the workplace. <br /> 2. Businesses must provide written justification to local health officials, upon request, explaining why an employee is not required to wear a facial covering in the workplace. At minimum, facial coverings (masks) should be cloth/fabric and cover an individuals nose, mouth, and chin.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Personnel should work from home when possible and feasible with business operations<br /> 2. Limit travel as much as possible <br /> 3. Stagger arrival of all employees and guests<br /> 4. Cancel/postpone in person events when social distancing guidelines cannot be met<br /> 5. Establish maximum capacity<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Require regular handwashing by employees <br /> 2. Place hand sanitizers in high-contact locations<br /> 3. Reduce sharing of work materials <br /> 4. No buffet in cafeteria <br /> 5.Utilize disposable tableware and other materials<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Frequent disinfection of desks, workstations, and high-contact surfaces <br /> 2. Daily disinfection of common areas<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Require employees to stay home if symptomatic<br /> 2. Immediately isolate and seek medical care for any individual who develops symptoms while at work <br /> 3. Immediately report employee or customer infections to the local health district.<br /> 4. Work with local health department to identify potentially exposed individuals to help facilitate appropriate communication/contact tracing.<br /> 5. Shutdown shop/floor for deep sanitation if possible. <br /> 6. Professionally clean and sanitize site/location.<br /> 7. Reopen in consultation with the local health department.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Now allowed to resume </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Plan to reopen in Fall </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.ohiobar.org/public-resources/commonly-asked-law-questions-results/labor--employment/covid-19-coronavirus-and-your-job/"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-17 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/responsible/General-Office-Environments.pdf"> General Office Environments </a><a target="_blank" href="https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/responsible-restart-ohio/Responsible-Protocols/"> Responsible Protocols </a><a target="_blank" href="https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/Directors-Stay-Safe-Ohio-Order.pdf"> Executive Order </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Oklahoma')" data-value="39" class="collapsible">Oklahoma</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> No Stay at home order </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://www.okc.gov/home/showdocument?id=17315" target="_blank"> Proclamation of State of Emergency </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://www.okcommerce.gov/wp-content/uploads/Open-Up-and-Recover-Safely-Plan.pdf" target="_blank"> Open Up and Recover Safely Plan </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Personal care Salons, barbershops, spas, pet groomers, etc.; Tattoo parlors<br /> 2. Outdoor and recreation State parks; Gyms<br /> 3. Food and drink Restaurant dining; Bars<br /> 4. Entertainment Movie theaters, sports venues, museums; Nightclubs<br /> 5. Houses of worship<br /> 6. Industries Offices<br /> 7. Summer camps (church and school) </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Retail and other essential businesses and organizations should continue to follow general CDC guidelines. All employers need to consider how best to decrease the spread of COVID-19 and lower the impact in your workplace. This should include activities to:<br /> 1. prevent and reduce transmission among employees,<br /> 2. maintain healthy business operations, and<br /> 3. maintain a healthy work environment.<br /> <br /> COVID-19 Business Sign Kit for signage can be found here, https://healthokgov.app.box.com/v/COVID19-BusinessSignKit.<br /> <br /> Please note this guidance is not comprehensive, it is intended to serve as a tool to help offices and business owners establish general protocols encountered in various situations. Effective safety measures that protect employees and citizens are critical to a successful reopening of our great state. There are unique situations not covered here, and we rely on collaboration with our local officials, businesses and citizens using their best judgement during this unprecedented time. <br /> The following are minimum guidelines that apply to administrative offices. Some workplaces, dependent on industry, risk level, and phase may have stricter regulations. For more information regarding sector-specific business guidance, please visit this link: https://www.okcommerce.gov/covid19/ours-plan/ </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Ensure the ability to quickly set up safe and efficient testing for symptomatic individuals </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. CDC recommendations encourage employers to conduct daily health checks<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Encourage employees to wear cloth face coverings in the workplace, if appropriate<br /> 2. Suggested guidelines regarding use of masks and other personal protective equipment can be found on the CDC website along with the Oklahoma Department of Commerce website.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Businesses can resume unrestricted staffing at their worksites by observing proper CDC-recommended social distancing protocols<br /> 2. It is at the discretion of business owners or local officials to determine when and if social distancing measures should be applied.<br /> 3. Business owners should use their best judgement taking into account factors such as location and size of venue when determining the appropriate levels of social distancing and group size.<br /> 4. Businesses operating by appointment only may begin operating by appointment and walk-in at their discretion<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Ensure that access to handwashing/hand sanitizing facilities and supplies are available for employees and visitors. <br /> 2. Encourage employees and visitors to use good hygiene including proper handwashing and observe respiratory etiquette<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Businesses are encouraged to develop, implement, and maintain and revise a cleaning and disinfecting plan for your workplace. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Actively encourage sick employees to stay home<br /> 2. Take action if an employee is suspected or confirmed to have COVID-19 infection:<br /> In most cases, you do not need to shut down your facility. If it has been less than 7 days since the sick employee has been in the facility, close off any areas used for prolonged periods of time by the sick person:<br /> Wait 24 hours before cleaning and disinfecting to minimize potential for other employees being exposed to respiratory droplets. If waiting 24 hours is not feasible, wait as long as possible.<br /> During this waiting period, open outside doors and windows to increase air circulation in these areas.<br /> 3. Identify where and how workers might be exposed to COVID-19 at work. Employers are responsible for providing a safe and healthy workplace<br /> 4. Conduct a thorough hazard assessment of the workplace to identify potential workplace hazards related to COVID-19. <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Elective Surgical Procedures resume </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Reopening come Fall </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.okcommerce.gov/covid19/"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-11 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.okcommerce.gov/covid19/ours-plan/"> OURs Plan </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.okcommerce.gov/wp-content/uploads/Administrative-Office-Guidance.pdf"> Employer Guidance Administrative Offices </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html"> CDC Interim Guidance for Business and Employers </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Oregon')" data-value="40" class="collapsible">Oregon</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home order expired, reopening in progress </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://www.oregon.gov/gov/admin/Pages/eo_20-25.aspx" target="_blank"> Stay at Home Order Expired </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://www.oregon.gov/gov/admin/Pages/eo_20-27.aspx" target="_blank"> Plan for Rebuilding a Safe and Strong Oregon </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Outdoor and recreation (Some state parks, outdoor recreation facilities; Gyms in some counties)<br /> 2. Food and drink (Restaurant dining in some counties - Ensure tables are spaced at least 6 feet apart so that at least 6 feet between parties is maintained, including when customers approach or leave tables. Limit parties to 10 or fewer)<br /> 3. Retail stores<br /> 4. Personal care (Salons, barber shops in some countries)<br /> 5. Limit local gatherings to 25 with no traveling </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> 1. Know the signs and symptoms of COVID-19 and what to do if employees develop symptoms at the workplace<br /> 2. Understand how COVID-19 is transmitted from one person to another-namely, through coughing, sneezing, talking, touching, or via objects touched by someone with the virus<br /> 3. Make health and safety a priority by implementing safeguards to protect employees and the public. Federal and state guidelines, including sector-specific guidance, will help you determine which safeguards are recommended or are required<br /> 4. Consider modifying employee schedules and travel to reduce unnecessary close physical contact (physical distance of less than (6) six feet between people).<br /> 5. Be aware of protected leave requirements and plan ahead for any anticipated workforce adjustments </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Consider regular health checks (e.g., temperature and respiratory symptom screening) or symptom self-report of employees, if job-related and consistent with business necessity. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Some employers are required to have employees and contractors wear masks, face shields or face coverings and transit agencies are required to have riders wear face coverings. When masks or face coverings are required an employer must provide for exceptions and accommodations to comply with applicable laws. Employers should review and implement the Mask and Face Covering Guidance for Business, Transit and the Public to ensure compliance with the requirements and recommendations. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Consider modifying employee schedules and travel to reduce unnecessary close physical contact (physical distance of less than (6) six feet between people).<br /> 2. Identify positions appropriate for telework or partial telework, including consideration of telework for employees who are at higher risk for severe COVID-19 complications due to underlying medical conditions identified by the CDC.<br /> 3. Stagger or rotate work schedules or shifts at worksites to ensure employees are able to sufficiently maintain physical distancing.<br /> 4. Limit non-essential work travel.<br /> 5. Implement physical distancing measures consistent with the Governor's Executive Orders and state guidance.<br /> 6. Increase physical space between workers. This may include modifications such as markings on the floor demonstrating appropriate spacing or installing plexiglass shields, tables or other barriers to block airborne particles and maintain distances. Review and follow any sector-specific guidance issued by the state that recommends or requires specific physical distancing measures.<br /> 7. Restrict use of any shared items or equipment and require disinfection of equipment between uses.<br /> 8. Limit the number of employees gathering in shared spaces. Restrict use of shared spaces such as conference rooms and break rooms by limiting occupancy or staggering use. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Reinforce that meticulous hand hygiene (frequent and proper handwashing) is of utmost importance for all employees. Ensure that soap and water or alcohol-based (60-95%) hand sanitizer is provided in the workplace. Consider staging additional hand washing facilities and hand sanitizer for employees (and customer use, if applicable) in and around the workplace. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Regularly disinfect commonly touched surfaces (workstations, keyboards, telephones, handrails, doorknobs, etc.), as well as high traffic areas and perform other environmental cleaning. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Develop an action plan consistent with federal and state guidance if an employee develops symptoms while in the workplace, tests positive for COVID-19 or is determined to be presumptively positive by a public health authority </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Procedures resume </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Ordered closed for the academic year </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.oregon.gov/boli/WHD/OST/pages/index.aspx"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> California, Washington, Nevada and Oregon will form a joint task force to plan for reopening </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-17 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le2342C.pdf"> Employers </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Pennsylvania')" data-value="41" class="collapsible">Pennsylvania</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home order expired June 4 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="N/A" target="_blank"> Stay-at-Home Order Lifted for Aggressive Mitigation </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://www.governor.pa.gov/plan-for-pennsylvania/" target="_blank"> Plan for Pennsylvania </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Yellow Phase:<br /> 1. Large Gatherings of More than 25 Prohibited<br /> 2. In-Person Retail, Curbside and Delivery Preferable <br /> 3. Indoor Recreation, Health and Wellness Facilities and Personal Care Services (such as gyms, spas, hair salons, nail salons and other entities that provide massage therapy), and all Entertainment (such as casinos, theaters) Remain Closed<br /> 4. Restaurants and Bars (Outdoor Dining) <br /> <br /> Green Phase:<br /> 1. All Businesses Operating at 50% Occupancy in the Yellow Phase May Increase to 75% Occupancy<br /> 2. Large gatherings of more than 250 prohibited<br /> 3. Restaurants and bars (50% occupancy)<br /> 4. Personal care services (hair salons and barbershops - 50% occupancy and by appointment only)<br /> 5. Indoor recreation, health and wellness facilities, and personal care services (such as gyms and spas) - 50% occupancy with appointments strongly encouraged<br /> 6. All entertainment (casinos, theaters, and shopping malls - 50% occupancy)<br /> 7. Construction activity may return to full capacity with continued implementation of protocols<br /> 8. Child Care </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> 1.All businesses that have been conducting their operations in whole or in part remotely through individual teleworking of its employees must continue telework operations for each of those employees. <br /> 2. Clean and disinfect high-touch areas frequently and continue to regularly clean all other areas of the building<br /> 3. Establish and implement a plan in case the business is exposed to a probable or confirmed case of COVID-19<br /> 4. If any employee who was in close contact remain asymptomatic, the employees should adhere to the practices set out by the CDC in its April 8, 2020 Interim Guidance for Implementing Safety Practice for Critical Infrastructure Workers Who May Have Had Exposure to a Person with Suspected or Confirmed COVID-19<br /> 5. Informing employees that if they have symptoms (i.e., fever, cough, or shortness of breath), they should notify their supervisor and stay home<br /> 6. Taking each employees temperature before they enter the business and sending home those who have a temperature of 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit, or higher. Ensure employees practice social distancing while waiting to have temperatures screened<br /> 7. Advising sick employees to follow CDC-recommended steps, including not returning to work until the CDC criteria to discontinue home isolation are met, in consultation with health care providers and state and local health departments<br /> 8. Employers are encouraged to implement liberal paid time off for employees who do not return to work for the reasons set forth above<br /> 9. Prevent large groups from entering or leaving the building by staggering work start and stop times<br /> 10. Limit the number of people in employee common areas, like locker rooms or break rooms, and ensure these areas are cleaned frequently<br /> 11 Conduct meetings and trainings virtually. If a meeting needs to be held in person, limit the number of employees to 10 and maintain a social distance of six feet<br /> 12. Make sure employees have access to soap and water to wash their hands, hand sanitizer and disinfectant wipes<br /> 13. Provide non-medical masks for employees to wear at all times and make it mandatory to wear masks while on the work site. Employers may approve masks obtained or made by employees according to Department of Health policies<br /> 14. Make sure the facility has enough employees as applicable to follow these protocols and conduct business effectively and safely<br /> 15. Discourage non-essential visitors from entering the business premises<br /> 16. Communicate these procedures to all employees to ensure that everyone knows how to be safe. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Take each employee's temperature before they enter the business and sending home those who have a temperature of 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit, or higher. Ensure employees practice social distancing while waiting to have temperatures screened. https://www.governor.pa.gov/covid-19/business-guidance/<br /> <br /> 2. Inform employees that if they have symptoms (i.e., fever, cough, or shortness of breath), they should notify their supervisor and stay home.<br /> 3. Advise sick employees to follow CDC-recommended steps, including not returning to work until the CDC criteria to discontinue home isolation are met, in consultation with health care providers and state and local health departments. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> Provide non-medical masks for employees to wear at all times and make it mandatory to wear masks while on the work site. Employers may approve masks obtained or made by employees according to Department of Health policies. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Ensure employees practice social distancing while waiting to have temperatures screened.<br /> 2. Conduct meetings and trainings virtually. If a meeting needs to be held in person, limit the number of employees to 10 and maintain a social distance of six feet.<br /> 3. Install shields or other barriers at registers and check-out areas to physically separate cashiers and customers, or take other measures to maintain social distancing between customers and employees.<br /> 4. Conduct business with the public by appointment only, whenever possible. <br /> 5. If appointment-only service is not feasible, limit the number of people inside the building to no more than 50% of the total maximum occupancy.<br /> 6. Encourage customers to use online ordering by providing delivery or pick-up options.<br /> 7. Designate a specific time for people at high risk, including those over the age of 65 to use the business at least once a week. 8.stagger work start and stop times for employees when practicable to prevent gatherings of large groups entering or leaving the premises at the same time;<br /> 9.provide sufficient amount of space for employees to have breaks and meals while maintaining a social distance of 6 feet, while arranging seating to have employees facing forward and not across from each other in eating and break settings; <br /> 10.If a meeting must be held in person, limit the meeting to the fewest number of employees possible, not to exceed 10 employees at one time, and maintain a social distance of 6 feet;<br /> 11.prohibit non-essential visitors from entering the premises of the business<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Make sure employees have access to soap and water to wash their hands, hand sanitizer and disinfectant wipes. 2. schedule handwashing breaks for employees at least every hour; </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. In addition to maintaining pre-existing cleaning protocols established in the business, clean and disinfect high touch areas routinely in accordance with guidelines issued by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), in spaces that are accessible to customers, tenants, or other individuals.<br /> 2. Maintain pre-existing cleaning protocols established by the business for all other areas of the building.<br /> 3. Modify the hours of business so that there is enough time to clean and restock. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. If any employee who was in close contact remain asymptomatic, the employees should adhere to the practices set out by the CDC in its April 8, 2020 Interim Guidance for Implementing Safety Practice for Critical Infrastructure Workers Who May Have Had Exposure to a Person with Suspected or Confirmed COVID-19.<br /> 2. If the affected employee becomes sick during the workday, the person should be sent home immediately. Surfaces in the employee's workspace should be cleaned and disinfected after waiting 24 hours. Information on other employees who had contact with the ill employee during the time the employee had symptoms and 48 hours prior to symptoms should be compiled. Others at the workplace with close contact within 6 feet of the employee during this time are considered exposed.<br /> 3. Promptly notify employees who were close contacts of any known exposure to COVID-19 at the business premises, consistent with applicable confidentiality laws. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Providers may resume non-urgent and elective care in addition to providing urgent and emergency care, only when appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) is available and telemedicine is not clinically sufficient </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Open Now:<br /> 1.Postsecondary institutions and adult basic education programs<br /> <br /> July 1st:<br /> 1. Elementary and secondary schools in the states yellow and green phases may resume in-person instruction and activities<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.uc.pa.gov/COVID-19/Pages/Services-for-PA-COVID19.aspx"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Massachusetts and Delaware will form a joint task force to plan for reopening the economy </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-18 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/20200415-SOH-worker-safety-order.pdf"> Worker Safety Order </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/COVID-19-Reopening-Businesses-Flyer-8-5x11-1.pdf"> Flyer for Businesses </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Puerto Rico')" data-value="42" class="collapsible">Puerto Rico</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-15 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://www.estado.pr.gov/en/executive-orders/" target="_blank"> Executive Order 41 </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right">N/A</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Food and drink (Restaurants - 25% of its capacity)<br /> 2. Personal care (Salons, barbershops; Pet grooming)<br /> 3. Retail (Retail stores; Outdoor malls - Shopping centers with an open format will not be able to allow people that exceed 50% of their capacity)<br /> 4. Outdoor and recreation (Beaches)<br /> 5. In-person religious services may be provided as long as they comply with the guidelines for reopening religious services<br /> 6. Armories (50% capacity) and outdoor polygons<br /> <br /> Remain closed: <br /> 1. Cinemas, play areas, and valet' parking<br /> 2. Gyms </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> 1. All employees have to avoid sharing desks, work tools, computers, mobile phones, etc. The number of employees working in the office area has to be kept low. Every employee who can work from home will do so<br /> 2. During the active period of the pandemic, visits to the building will be restricted. Only visits that are strictly necessary for business purposes will be allowed. Visitors will be subject to the requirements of this procedure<br /> 3. Employees who are in the high risk group (pregnant, over 65 years of age or personnel with comorbid conditions) human resources personnel will be communicating with this population to verify if they are willing to work, and offer them the options available for their benefit. Stronger measures will be taken with this vulnerable population.<br /> 4. Keep social distance at least 6 feet. <br /> 5. The use of face masks is compulsory for all employees at all times. Employees will use the personal protective equipment that they normally use according to their tasks and those stipulated by the establishment's risk assessment </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Employers must inform and encourage workers to monitor themselves to see if they have signs and symptoms of COVID-19 and of suspecting any possible exposure.<br /> 2. The body temperature reading will be taken of all employees daily as long as the pandemic emergency remains active. If an employee's temperature is above 37.5 C 0 99.5 F, they will be denied access to the facility. Access will also be denied to any employee who prevents their body temperature reading from being taken.<br /> 3. In the absence of a thermometer, a questionnaire will be taking place for employees and visitors:<br /> <br /> 1. You have been in contact with someone with symptoms:<br /> a. Fever (greater than 38 degrees)<br /> b. Dry cough<br /> c. Difficulty breathing<br /> d. Fatigue<br /> e. Shortness of breath<br /> f. All of the above<br /> g. None of the above<br /> 2. Do you have any of these symptoms:<br /> a. Fever (greater than 38 degrees)<br /> b. Dry cough<br /> c. Difficulty breathing<br /> d. Fatigue<br /> e. Shortness of breath<br /> f. All of the above<br /> g. None of the above<br /> 3. During the past 48 hours you were in contact with someone who was traveling outside of Puerto Rico:<br /> a. Yes<br /> b. No<br /> <br /> 4. Temperature readings will be recorded<br /> 5. Employees who have a body temperature above 37.5 C or 99.5 F will be sent home immediately and will have to be quarantined<br /> 6. The Human Resources department will have a list of employees who did not pass the temperature monitoring and will be in contact with them during the 14-day quarantine period for monitoring purposes<br /> 7. All employees who are experiencing symptoms of fever, cough and / or have respiratory distress will have to stay home and not report to work<br /> 8. Any employee who shows up for work but shows respiratory distress, cough and / or fever will be sent home immediately. These employees will not be allowed to return to work until they have completed the 14-day quarantine period. The Human Resources department will keep in touch with the employee during the quarantine period for monitoring purposes<br /> 9. If an employee has been in contact with a person who is showing symptoms of fever, cough and/or has respiratory distress in the past 14 days, they should immediately report it to their supervisor. It is recommended that the employee observe a quarantine period of 14 days<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. The use of face masks is compulsory for all employees at all times. Employees will use the personal protective equipment that they normally use according to their tasks and those stipulated by the establishment's risk assessment<br /> 2. Employees will be trained in the use, handling, limitations, cleaning and disposal of personal protective equipment. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. The number of employees in a bathroom will be controlled in order to maintain distance between employees. Because the size of restrooms can vary between floors, the number of employees that will be allowed inside the restrooms at a time will be determined and reported to employees by plant management. The same applies to the number of employees who may be waiting in line. Employees waiting in line will be 6 feet from each other. Marks will be placed 6 feet apart between each one so that the employees who are waiting in line keep distance. After an employee leaves the bathroom, the next employee will be allowed entry.<br /> 2. The number of meetings should be kept to a minimum as possible. If a meeting is necessary, there must be a 6 foot space between each employee during the meeting. The meeting must be held in an open space<br /> 3. Keep social distance at least 6 feet. The use of masks will be compulsory at all times while employees are working </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> All employees must wash their hands with soap frequently at least every 30 minutes for periods of 20 seconds and must use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. This requirement must be applied before starting your work shift, after each visit to the bathroom, before and after eating, and at the end of your work shift. Any contact with the face (eyes, nose, mouth, etc.) must be avoided. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. All available resources for cleaning and disinfection will be increased each time this procedure has to be applied. <br /> 2. All cleaning will be done by maintenance personnel in all areas of the building using suitable materials. <br /> 3. Hand sanitizer stations have been placed in various areas of the building<br /> 4. An itinerary for cleaning and disinfecting the work area, bathrooms, dining area and common areas is established. <br /> 5. You will be using the EPA approved disinfection and cleaning products on your N list. You will be cleaning and disinfecting in the morning and afternoon. <br /> 6. Antibacterial cleaning products will be provided so that employees can sanitize their work areas. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. In the event that an employee communicates suspicions, virus symptoms or has received a positive diagnosis to his supervisor or manager, Company Name by HIPPA Law will NOT disclose the name of the affected employee.<br /> 2. The employee will be oriented who, if they present any symptoms, cannot appear at the facility and must report their situation to their supervisor<br /> 3. Management will proceed to investigate the exposure that other employees have had with the employee in question (asking him) and will take the following actions: Isolation of diagnosed employee, Identification of the contacts that the diagnosed with suspicion or confirmation of positive has had, Notification to those who have had direct contact with the diagnosed, Disinfection of the areas, Return to work of the diagnosed, Register of cases in the register of Occupational Injuries and Diseases. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Elective surgeries Resume </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Ordered closed for the academic year </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="Information Coming Soon"> Information Coming Soon </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-09 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/puerto-rico-s-secretary-of-labor-issues-59994/"> Guidance on New Employer Requirements </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.dlapiper.com/en/us/insights/publications/2020/05/puerto-rico-starts-reopening-businesses-employers-must-establish-exposure-control-plans/"> Employers must establish exposure control plans </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.trabajo.pr.gov/covid19.asp"> Puerto Rico Department of Labor and Human Services </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Rhode Island')" data-value="43" class="collapsible">Rhode Island</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home expired May 8th- reopening in progres </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-32.pdf" target="_blank"> Stay at Home Order 32 </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://www.reopeningri.com/" target="_blank"> Reopening RI </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. All state beaches and parks<br /> 2. Retail stores<br /> 3. Industries Offices (33% of the workforce can return)<br /> 4. Personal care Hair salons, barbershops<br /> 5. Food and drink (Restaurants for outdoor dining - 50% seating capacity)<br /> 6. Churches, mosques, temples, and other faith-based (Occupancy capped at 25%) <br /> 7. Gyms & Fitness (Class sizes need to be limited to 15 people, or 1 person per 150 square feet (whichever is less)) </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> 1. All workplaces to develop a COVID-19 Control Plan. Template available at ReopeningRI.com.<br /> 2. Social distancing procedures<br /> 3. Procedures for ensuring wearing of face coverings<br /> 4. Procedures for decontamination of surfaces<br /> 5. Procedures for responding to a positive case or outbreak. Each organization should have a plan to ensure that employees who are required to isolate based on a positive test for COVID-19, or are required to quarantine as a result of exposure, can stay out of the workplace until cleared to return<br /> 6. Procedures for minimizing access to the establishment by COVID-19 positive or symptomatic individuals<br /> 7. Businesses and organizations must place posters educating employees, customers, and<br /> visitors about how to protect themselves in accordance with RIDOH regulations </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. At a minimum, businesses and organizations must screen employees and visitors for self-reported symptoms consistent with COVID-19 and other COVID-19 risk factors upon entering the building.<br /> 2. Screenings can be conducted verbally, by app, by phone, or by another method of the employer's choosing including, if necessary, the posting of an informational poster that communicates the screening requirements.<br /> 3. Businesses and organizations may also choose to supplement screening questions with temperature checks. 4. https://health.ri.gov/forms/screening/COVID19_Employee_Screening_Tool.pdf - https://health.ri.gov/otherlanguages/spanish/forms/screening/COVID19_Employee_ Screening_Tool.pdf <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Employers must provide appropriate face coverings to their employees. Either a cloth mask or surgical face mask is acceptable. Respirators such as N95 masks should be reserved for designated healthcare workers.<br /> 2.
