Employees that require more extensive facial coverings due to industry specific safety regulations, laws or guidelines should continue to comply with the PPE requirements outlined within their respective industry-specific laws, regulations, and guidelines (i.e. medical professionals, professionals who use respiratory equipment, and professionals who handle hazardous waste.)<br /> 3. Face coverings are required unless an employee and/or visitor can easily, continuously, and measurably maintain at least six (6) feet of distance from other employees and/or visitors for the duration of his or her work and/or time in a building 4. Under Executive Order 20-30 all employees and visitors are required to wear face coverings. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. All persons should remain at least 6 feet apart at all times. If social distancing is not feasible, individuals must minimize time in violation of social distancing, and additional precautions should be taken. Procedures that cannot be executed with social distancing should be documented by businesses in the written COVID-19 Control Plan.<br /> 2. Furthermore, businesses are encouraged to maintain consistent work crews and mitigate the number of other employees that each employee is exposed to in the workplace to the furthest extent feasible. Suggested workforce management practices for businesses to minimize the spread of COVID-19 among employees include:<br /> 2a. Organizing work crews into "teams" or "pods" that do not interact to mitigate the risk of transmission.<br /> 2b. Staggering shifts or flexing work schedules to allow for fewer employees in any given workspace at any one time.<br /> 2c. Closing communal spaces where possible (break rooms, conference rooms, etc.) </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Businesses must ensure that any individual who enters the business premises has ready access to a handwashing station with soap and running water and/or hand sanitizer at all times.<br /> 2. Businesses must provide employees with time to wash hands often if sanitizer is not provided.<br /> 3. Employees should wash their hands often with soap and water for 20 seconds.<br /> 4. Employees must always wash hands immediately after removing gloves and conducting cleaning procedures.<br /> 5. If soap and water are unavailable and hands are not visibly dirty, a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol may be used.<br /> 6. If hands are visibly dirty, always wash hands with soap and water. 7.Must provide employees with cleaning/disinfecting wipes and/or cleaning materials so that commonly used surfaces can be wiped down<br /> 8. Ensure that any individual who enters the premises has ready access to a handwashing station with soap and running water and/or hand sanitizer at all times.<br /> 9.Allow breaks for employees to wash their hands<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. The CDC recommends cleaning surfaces with soap and then applying disinfectant.<br /> 2. RIDOH requires cleanings of business establishments at least once daily. In addition, commonly touched surfaces, such as shared workstations, elevator buttons, door handles and railings should be cleaned in accordance with CDC guidance for specific industries.<br /> 3. Businesses can prepare a bleach solution by mixing 5 tablespoons (1/3 cup) bleach per gallon of water or 4 teaspoons bleach per quart of water. WARNING: Never mix bleach with ammonia or any other cleanser.<br /> 4. Note that these are minimum cleaning requirements - increased cleaning standards may apply to specific industries dependent on the type of work performed.<br /> 5. Sector specific guidance for non-critical retailers be found at https://www.reopeningri.com/; more sector-specific guidance will be available on this website over time. <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> If an employee tests positive, the business should immediately contact RIDOH at 401-222-8022, or 211 after hours, so they can assist in contact tracing and provide further instruction. 2. In the event an employee becomes ill during the workday, he or she should be sent home immediately. Once a sick employee and those with possible exposure have left the impacted area(s), the area(s) must be closed off for heightened cleaning and disinfection in accordance with CDC protocols and guidelines. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Elective medical procedures may resume under safety guidelines </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Ordered closed for the academic year </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="http://www.dlt.state.ri.us/pdfs/COVID-19%20Workplace%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Massachusetts and Delaware will form a joint task force to plan for reopening the economy </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-18 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.reopeningri.com/resource_pdfs/RI-General_business_organization_guidance-05.13.20.pdf"> General business/organization guidelines </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.reopeningri.com/resource_pdfs/COVID-19-Control_Plan_Fillable_Template-Final-5.13.20.pdf"> COVID-19 control plan template </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on South Carolina')" data-value="44" class="collapsible">South Carolina</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home order expired may 4 - Reopening in pr </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Executive-Orders/2020-05-15%20FILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-36%20-%20Additional%20Incremental%20Modification%20of%20Non-Essential%20Business%20Closures.pdf" target="_blank"> Executive Order 36 </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://governor.sc.gov/executive-branch/acceleratesc" target="_blank"> accelerateSC </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Retail (Retail stores - 20% occupancy or five (5) customers per 1,000 square feet, whichever is less)<br /> 2. Outdoor and recreation (Beaches, piers, docks, etc.; Gyms; Pools)<br /> 3. Food and drink (Restaurant dining - 50% capacity) <br /> 4. Personal care 9Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors etc.)<br /> 5. Child care centers </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> As you develop your COVID-19 related processes, keep in mind the population of people who are at greater risk of contracting this virus and to having more difficulty in fighting it (those with preexisting conditions like diabetes, heart or lung diseases, as well as the elderly). Continue to follow the advice of public health officials, including:<br /> 1. Staying at least 6 feet apart or when that is not possible, wearing a cloth face covering or respirator,<br /> 2. Frequent hand washing with soap & water or use of approved hand sanitizers,<br /> 3. Regular cleaning of frequently touched surfaces (door handles, phones, keyboards, etc.),<br /> 4. Removing frequently touched surfaces that can be removed (for example trash can lids), and<br /> 5. Increasing ventilation or percent outdoor air where possible.<br /> 6. Please see the CDC Guidance documents for other recommendations that may be applicable to your work environment, as well as for specific information on cleaning and disinfecting different types of work surfaces. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Not Recommended</strong><br> 1. There is currently no method for screening for asymptomatic infected people. Screening of asymptomatic individuals with testing is not recommended because the testing available at this time cannot provide assurance that someone will not become sick after the test is performed. 2. The gold-standard test, called a PCR, is a snapshot in time that only tells whether the individual is infected at that time. Antibody tests currently available are not accurate and cannot guarantee protection from becoming infected again. 3. DHEC recommends that only individuals with symptoms consistent with COVID-19 be tested for the disease. 4. The safest approach is to assume everyone is infected and follow the recommended guidelines that are in place to avoid transmission of the virus. 5.Negative COVID-19 testing is not recommended or required for people to return to work. Even workers who were confirmed to have COVID-19 do not have to have negative testing to return to work.
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. People who have symptoms should stay at home until symptoms resolve. Be sure your leave policies reinforce this as well as encourage self-isolation when symptoms are present.<br /> 2. Employees should be considered sick if they have symptoms of acute respiratory illness like shortness of breath, coughing and/or fever of 100.0 F or greater.<br /> 3. Negative COVID-19 testing is not recommended or required for people to return to work. Even workers who were confirmed to have COVID-19 do not have to have negative testing. Instead, DHEC recommends that employees not come to work until 7 days have passed since their symptoms began AND they are free of fever (100.0 F [37.8 C] or greater using an oral thermometer) for 3 days without the use of fever-reducing medicines AND their other symptoms have improved. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Employees should be encouraged to wear masks or cloth face coverings, especially when in settings in which social distancing is not feasible.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Stay at least 6 feet apart or when that is not possible, wearing a cloth face covering or respirator<br /> 2. Avoid sharing indoor space unless it is essential. In that scenario, employees should be encouraged to wear masks or cloth face coverings.<br /> 3. Consider staggering start times for employees </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Frequent hand washing with soap & water or use of approved hand sanitizers </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Regular cleaning of frequently touched surfaces (door handles, phones, keyboards, etc.),<br /> 2. Removing frequently touched surfaces that can be removed (for example trash can lids), and<br /> 3. Increasing ventilation or percent outdoor air where possible. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. If an employee is confirmed to have COVID-19, employers should inform fellow employees of their possible exposure to COVID-19 in the workplace but maintain confidentiality as required by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). <br /> 2. Employees exposed to a co-worker with confirmed COVID-19 should monitor themselves for symptoms and may be recommended for a 14-day quarantine based on the DHEC Epidemiology team's risk assessment. Please reach out to DHEC (contact info below) if you have any questions about the plan for coworkers. <br /> 3. If possible, the area where the infected individual worked should be isolated for 24 hours and then cleaned and disinfected. If it is not possible to delay access to the area, the workers who perform cleaning/disinfecting should wear appropriate PPE for protection against the cleaning materials and the virus </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Partially Opened </strong><br> Some Elective Outpatient Surgeries Resume </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Ordered closed for the academic year </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.scworks.org/about-us/statewide-centers"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-18 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://scdhec.gov/infectious-diseases/viruses/coronavirus-disease-2019-covid-19/businesses-employers-covid-19"> General Guidelines for Close Contact Service Providers </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.scdhec.gov/sites/default/files/media/document/DHEC-Employer-Return-to-Work-Guidance-05.05.2020_1.pdf"> DHEC COVID-19 Re-Opening Guidance for Businesses </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.scdhec.gov/sites/default/files/media/document/Business-COVID-guidance%2520FINAL-3272020.pdf"> DHEC Interim Guidance for Businesses and Employers </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on South Dakota')" data-value="45" class="collapsible">South Dakota</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> No stay at home order </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://covid.sd.gov/docs/2020-20.pdf" target="_blank"> Executive Order </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://covid.sd.gov/docs/COVID_SDPlan_BackToNormal.pdf" target="_blank"> South Dakota's Back to Normal Plan </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Business are encouraged to consider the guidelines as they resume normal operations, and also must adhere to any local restrictions<br /> 2. Daycares<br /> 4. Movie theaters (50% capacity)<br /> 5. Churches<br /> 6. School district should make its own decisions about the remainder of the school year </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> For most employers, protecting workers will depend on emphasizing basic infection prevention measures. As appropriate, all employers should implement good hygiene and infection control practices, including:<br /> 1. Promote frequent and thorough hand washing, including by providing workers, customers, and worksite visitors with a place to wash their hands<br /> 2. Encourage workers to stay home if they are sick.<br /> 3. Encourage respiratory etiquette, including covering coughs and sneezes.<br /> 4. Provide customers and the public with tissues and trash receptacles.<br /> 5. Employers should explore whether they can establish policies and practices, such as flexible worksites (e.g., telecommuting) and flexible work hours (e.g., staggered shifts), to increase the physical distance among employees and between employees and others if state and local health authorities recommend the use of social distancing strategies.<br /> 6. Discourage workers from using other workers' phones, desks, offices, or other work tools and equipment, when possible.<br /> 7. Maintain regular housekeeping practices, including routine cleaning and disinfecting of surfaces, equipment, and other elements of the work environment.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1.Employers should inform and encourage employees to self-monitor for signs and symptoms of COVID-19 if they suspect possible exposure. 2.Prior to workday, screen employees<br /> https://doh.sd.gov/documents/COVID19/BusinessScreening_Q&A.pdf<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Employers are obligated to provide their workers with PPE needed to keep them safe while performing their jobs. The types of PPE required during a COVID-19 outbreak will be based on the risk of being infected with SARS-CoV-2 while working and job tasks that may lead to exposure. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Employers should explore whether they can establish policies and practices, such as flexible worksites (e.g., telecommuting) and flexible work hours (e.g., staggered shifts), to increase the physical distance among employees and between employees and others if state and local health authorities recommend the use of social distancing strategies. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Promote frequent and thorough hand washing, including by providing workers, customers, and worksite visitors with a place to wash their hands. If soap and running water are not immediately available, provide alcohol-based hand rubs containing at least 60% alcohol. Encourage good hygiene and sanitation practices, especially in high-traffic areas<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Maintain regular housekeeping practices, including routine cleaning and disinfecting of surfaces, equipment, and other elements of the work environment. When choosing cleaning chemicals, employers should consult information on Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)-approved disinfectant labels with claims against emerging viral pathogens. Products with EPA-approved emerging viral pathogens claims are expected to be effective against SARS-CoV-2 based on data for harder to kill viruses. Follow the manufacturer's instructions for use of all cleaning and disinfection products (e.g., concentration, application method and contact time, PPE). </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> If possible, isolate people suspected of having COVID-19 separately from those with confirmed cases of the virus to prevent further transmission-particularly in worksites where medical screening, triage, or healthcare activities occur, using either permanent (e.g., wall/different room) or temporary barrier (e.g., plastic sheeting). </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Now Open </strong><br> Elective Surgeries resume </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Plan to reopen come fall </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://dlr.sd.gov/covid_19_resources.aspx"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-18 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://covid.sd.gov/docs/COVID_SDPlan_BackToNormal.pdf"> Back to Normal Plan </a><a target="_blank" href="https://doh.sd.gov/documents/news/COVID_business_QA.pdf"> Workplace and Employer Resources & Recommendations </a><a target="_blank" href="https://doh.sd.gov/news/coronavirus.aspx%23Groups"> Community Guidance & Resources </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Tennessee')" data-value="46" class="collapsible">Tennessee</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home expired April 30--Regional reopening </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee35.pdf" target="_blank"> Executive Order 35 </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://www.tn.gov/content/dam/tn/governorsoffice-documents/covid-19-assets/Pledge_General.pdf" target="_blank"> Tennessee Pledge </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Outdoor and recreation (State parks; Gyms in most counties; Theaters, museums, amusement parks)<br /> 2. Food and drink (Restaurant dining in most counties - 50% of seating capacity. Limit tables to no more than 6 guests per table)<br /> 3. Retail stores in most counties (50% capacity) <br /> 4. Personal care (Salons, barbershops, etc. in most counties) </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> For All Businesses<br /> The State recommends safeguarding protocols for all businesses in Tennessee, including those that are reopening and those essential businesses that remained open during the Safer at Home order. These safeguarding protocols are based on the recommendations of the CDC and OSHA. To support the Tennessee Pledge, all employers and employees should take steps to reopen safely, help other industries be able to open more quickly, and allow Tennessee to remain healthy and open for business.<br /> <br /> Employers:<br /> 1. Allow employees to work from home as much as possible<br /> 2. Screen all employees reporting to work for COVID-19 symptoms <br /> 3. Temperature screening employees<br /> 4. Direct any employee who exhibits COVID-19 symptoms (i.e., answers yes to any of the screening questions or who is running a fever) to leave the premises immediately and seek medical care and/or COVID-19 testing, per Tennessee Department of Health and CDC guidelines. Employers should maintain the confidentiality of employee health information.<br /> 5. Implement workplace cleaning and disinfection practices, according to CDC guidelines, with regular sanitization of high-touch surfaces at least every two hours<br /> 6. Mitigate exposure in the workplace by implementing social distancing guidelines and modify scheduling<br /> 7. Plan for potential COVID-19 cases, and work with local health department officials when needed (e.g., monitor and trace COVID-19 cases, deep clean facilities)<br /> 8. Covered employers and employees should be aware of the provisions of the federal Families First Coronavirus Response Act, which allows for paid sick leave or expanded family and medical leave for specified reasons, such as for self quarantining or seeking a medical diagnosis for COVID-19 symptoms<br /> 9. Update the Employee Illness Policy to include the symptoms of "COVID-19" or create a COVID-19 specific policy. All staff should sign the policy, and the policy should be posted for confirmation<br /> 10. Limit self-service options (customer samples, communal packaging, food/beverages, etc.)<br /> 11. Post extensive signage on health policies, including the following documents, in the workplace to help educate building occupants on COVID-19 best practices:<br /> a. CDC guidance to stop the spread of germs<br /> b. CDC guidance on COVID-19 symptoms </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Screen all employees reporting to work for COVID-19 symptoms with the following questions:<br /> a. Have you been in close contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19?<br /> b. Are you experiencing a cough, shortness of breath or sore throat?<br /> c. Have you had a fever in the last 48 hours?<br /> d. Have you had new loss of taste or smell?<br /> e. Have you had vomiting or diarrhea in the last 24 hours?<br /> 2. Temperature screening employees:<br /> a. Best practice: employers to take temperatures onsite with a no-touch thermometer each day upon arrival at work<br /> b. Minimum: temperatures can be taken before arriving. Normal temperature should not exceed 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit<br /> 3. Direct any employee who exhibits COVID-19 symptoms (i.e., answers yes to any of the screening questions or who is running a fever) to leave the premises immediately and seek medical care and/or COVID-19 testing, per Tennessee Department of Health and CDC guidelines. Employers should maintain the confidentiality of employee health information. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> Wear a cloth face covering (not an N-95 or medical mask, which should be reserved for healthcare workers) while at work and in public to help protect against the spread of the virus. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Allow employees to work from home as much as possible<br /> 2. Mitigate exposure in the workplace by implementing social distancing guidelines and modify scheduling<br /> 3. Plan for potential COVID-19 cases, and work with local health department officials when needed (e.g., monitor and trace COVID-19 cases, deep clean facilities)<br /> 4. Limit self-service options (customer samples, communal packaging, food/beverages, etc.)<br /> 5. Practice recommended social distancing to the greatest extent possible- "Further is safer" </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Post extensive signage on health policies, including the following documents, in the workplace to help educate building occupants on COVID-19 best practices:<br /> a. CDC guidance to stop the spread of germs<br /> b. CDC guidance on COVID-19 symptoms<br /> 2. Increase hygiene practices-wash hands more frequently, avoid touching face, practice good respiratory etiquette when coughing or sneezing </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Implement workplace cleaning and disinfection practices, according to CDC guidelines, with regular sanitization of high-touch surfaces at least every two hours. 2.Place hand sanitizer stations in common areas<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> Direct any employee who exhibits COVID-19 symptoms (i.e., answers yes to any of the screening questions or who is running a fever) to leave the premises immediately and seek medical care and/or COVID-19 testing, per Tennessee Department of Health and CDC guidelines. Employers should maintain the confidentiality of employee health information. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Elective surgeries resume </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Reopening come Fall </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://dlr.sd.gov/covid_19_resources.aspx"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-18 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.tn.gov/governor/covid-19/economic-recovery/general-guidelines-for-businesses.html"> Tennessee Pledge General Business Guidelines </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.tn.gov/governor/covid-19/economic-recovery/office-guidelines.html"> Office Building Guidelines </a><a target="_blank" href="https://tngovecd.box.com/s/enyaq12o5k9mp63fwh95p5uehudaa16o"> Business Toolkit </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Texas')" data-value="47" class="collapsible">Texas</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home order expired April 30 - Reopening in </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://lrl.texas.gov/scanned/govdocs/Greg%20Abbott/2020/GA-21.pdf" target="_blank"> Executive Order </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://static.texastribune.org/media/files/1d486f159188580f63312da128be4db1/OpenTexas-Report.pdf?_ga=2.68039569.109894137.1588620631-1485244783.1588620631" target="_blank"> Texans Helping Texans: The Governor's Report to Open Texas </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now (All businesses currently operating at 25% capacity can expand their occupancy to 50% with certain exceptions):<br /> 1. Outdoor and recreation State parks; Pools; Gyms; Natural caverns<br /> 2. Retail stores, malls<br /> 3. Food and drink (Restaurant dining; Bars)<br /> 4. Entertainment (Movie theaters, museums, libraries; Bowling alleys, bingo halls, skating rinks, rodeos; Aquariums)<br /> 5. Personal care (Salons, barbershops, etc.; Massage and personal care)<br /> 6. Industries<br /> June 12th:<br /> 1. Restaurants may expand their occupancy levels to 75%<br /> 2. Counties with 10 or less active COVID-19 cases may expand their occupancy limits to 75%. Counties that fit this category but have not previously filed an attestation with DSHS will need to do so<br /> June 19:<br /> 1. Amusement parks and carnivals in counties with more than 1,000 confirmed positive cases of COVID-19 may open at 50% capacity<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> 1. Train all employees and contractors on appropriate cleaning and disinfection, hand hygiene, and respiratory etiquette.<br /> 2. Screen employees and contractors before coming into the business.<br /> 3. Send home any employee or contractor who has any of the following new or worsening signs or symptoms of possible COVID-19: Cough, Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, Chills, Repeated shaking with chills, Muscle pain, Headache, Sore throat, Loss of taste or smell, Diarrhea, Feeling feverish or a measured temperature greater than or equal to 100.0 degrees Fahrenheit, Known close contact with a person who is lab confirmed to have COVID-19.<br /> 4. Do not allow employees or contractors with new or worsening signs or symptoms listed above to return to work.<br /> 5. Do not allow an employee or contractor with known close contact to a person who is lab confirmed to have COVID-19 to return to work until the end of the 14 day self-quarantine period from the last date of exposure (with an exception granted for healthcare workers and critical infrastructure workers).<br /> 6. Conduct temperature checks on all employees and contractors at the beginning of their shift, where feasible.<br /> 7. Have employees and contractors wash or sanitize their hands upon entering the business.<br /> 8. Have employees and contractors maintain at least 6 feet separation from other individuals. If such distancing is not feasible, other measures such as face covering, hand hygiene, cough etiquette, cleanliness, and sanitation should be rigorously practiced.<br /> 9. As appropriate, stagger schedules for employees to minimize close contact.<br /> 10. Continue to encourage individuals to work remotely if possible.<br /> 11. If an employer provides a meal for employees and/or contractors, employers are recommended to have the meal individually packed for each individual.<br /> 12. Consistent with the actions taken by many employers across the state, consider having all employees and contractors wear cloth face coverings (over the nose and mouth). If available, employees and contractors should consider wearing non-medical grade face masks.<br /> 13. For employers who choose to require masks on their property employees should be instructed to understand that young children and persons who are unable to adjust or remove face coverings should not be regarded as suitable candidates for wearing face coverings. In this case, the decision is up to the individual or their parent, guardian or attendant. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Not Recommended</strong><br> The State's testing policy is aligned with CDC guidance and directed by DSHS. Testing is currently focused specifically on hospitalized patients, those in long-term care facilities, healthcare workers and first responders, and Texans over the age of 65. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Screen employees before coming into the business. Send home any employee or contractor who has any of the following new or worsening signs or symptoms of possible COVID-19:<br /> <br /> - Cough<br /> - Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing<br /> - Chills<br /> - Repeated shaking with chills<br /> - Muscle pain<br /> - Headache<br /> - Sore throat<br /> - Loss of taste or smell<br /> - Diarrhea<br /> - Feeling feverish or a measured temperature greater than or equal to 100.0 degrees Fahrenheit<br /> - Known close contact with a person who is lab confirmed to have COVID-19<br /> <br /> 2. Do not allow employees with the new or worsening signs or symptoms listed above to return to work until:<br /> a. In the case of an employee who was diagnosed with COVID-19, the individual may return to work when all three of the following criteria are met: at least 3 days (72 hours) have passed since recovery (resolution of fever without the use of fever-reducing medications); and the individual has improvement in respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, shortness of breath); and at least 7 days have passed since symptoms first appeared; or<br /> b. In the case of an employee who has symptoms that could be COVID-19 and does not get evaluated by a medical professional or tested for COVID-19, the individual is assumed to have COVID-19, and the individual may not return to work until the individual has completed the same three-step criteria listed above; or<br /> c. If the employee has symptoms that could be COVID-19 and wants to return to work before completing the above self-isolation period, the individual must obtain a medical professional's note clearing the individual for return based on an alternative diagnosis. 3. Conduct temperature checks on all employees and contractors at the beginning of their shift, where feasible<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Consistent with the actions taken by many employers across the state, consider having all employees wear cloth face coverings (over the nose and mouth). If available, employees should consider wearing non-medical grade face masks.<br /> 2. For employers who choose to require masks on their property employees should be instructed to understand that young children and persons who are unable to adjust or remove face coverings should not be regarded as suitable candidates for wearing face coverings. In this case, the decision is up to the individual or their parent, guardian or attendant. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Have employees maintain at least 6 feet separation from other individuals. If such distancing is not feasible, other measures such as face covering, hand hygiene, cough etiquette, cleanliness, and sanitation should be rigorously practiced.<br /> 2. If 6 feet of separation is not available between employees, contractors, and/or customers inside the facility, consider the use of engineering controls, such as dividers between individuals, to minimize the chances of transmission of COVID-19.<br /> 3. If an employer provides a meal for employees, employers are recommended to have the meal individually packed for each employee.<br /> 4. Configure your facility such that customers or patrons are separated by at least 6 feet from others not within the individual's group while at the facility. The individual's group may not exceed 10 individuals who go to the facility together. A group is defined as no more than 10 persons including the members of the household and those persons who traveled together to the event or facility. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Train all employees on appropriate cleaning and disinfection, hand hygiene, and respiratory etiquette.<br /> 2. Have employees wash or sanitize their hands upon entering the business.<br /> 3. Make hand sanitizer, disinfecting wipes, soap and water, or similar disinfectant readily available to employees and customers.<br /> 4. Place readily visible signage at the business to remind everyone of best hygiene practices.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Train all employees on appropriate cleaning and disinfection, hand hygiene, and respiratory etiquette.<br /> 2. Regularly and frequently clean and disinfect any regularly touched surfaces, such as doorknobs, tables, chairs, and restrooms.<br /> 3. Disinfect any items that come into contact with customers. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. In the case of an employee who was diagnosed with COVID-19, the individual may return to work when all three of the following criteria are met: at least 3 days (72 hours) have passed since recovery (resolution of fever without the use of fever-reducing medications); and the individual has improvement in respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, shortness of breath); and at least 7 days have passed since symptoms first appeared; or<br /> 2. Do not allow an employee with known close contact to a person who is lab-confirmed to have COVID-19 to return to work until the end of the 14 day self-quarantine period from the last date of exposure (with an exception granted for healthcare workers and critical infrastructure workers). </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Depends on facility - most have resumed. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Partial Reopening for Summer classes </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.trla.org/taking-time-off-work-covid-19-response"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-18 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus/opentexas.aspx#protocols"> Minimum Standard of Health Protocols </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus/docs/opentx/AllEmployers.pdf"> Protocols for all Employers </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus/docs/opentx/ProtocolsforAllOfficeBasedEmployers.pdf"> Protocols for All Office-Based Employers </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on US Virgin Islands')" data-value="48" class="collapsible">US Virgin Islands</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home Expired May 4-- Reopening in progress </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://usviupdate.com/2020/04/governor-bryan-issues-safer-at-home-order/" target="_blank"> Safer At Home Order </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right">N/A</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Restaurants (capacity of 25%)<br /> 2. Beaches (open for surfing, jogging, swimming and kayaking (but no sunbathing)<br /> 3. Golf courses (with safety protocols in place)<br /> 4. Pool facilities (25% capacity)<br /> 5. Many of the hotels, resorts, malls and shops </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> 1. All patrons are required to wear a face mask when entering a business.<br /> 2. All gatherings of people require face masks (except children 2 and younger or those with acute respiratory ailments).<br /> 3. Recreation facilities, such as gyms, tennis courts and golf courses may reopen as long as they maintain social distancing.<br /> 4. All contact sports, such as basketball, volleyball and football are prohibited.<br /> 5. Sports equipment must be properly sanitized and not shared.<br /> 6. Bowling alleys and movie theaters may reopen if they practice social distancing, but they may not sell food and drink or host parties.<br /> 7. Private offices may reopen, but all employees not critical to in-person services should be encouraged to work from home.<br /> 8. Government operations remain in their current hold pattern and all conditions for public interaction remain in place until further notice.<br /> 9. Private health care facilities may resume procedures if they follow required safety protocols.<br /> 10. Personal services, such as barbers, massage therapists and hair salons, may operate by appointment only and must employ strict hygiene guidelines and frequent sanitization procedure for all contact services and tools, including hand sanitizer for patrons and face masks for the entire time as possible.<br /> 11. For personal services businesses, no more than 5 customers will be allowed to wait at any given time and no more than 10 people, including employees, allowed in the establishment at a time.<br /> 12. Retail stores may not allow more than 10 individuals into the establishment at any time. The only exemptions are grocery stores and the previously exempted big box stores.<br /> 13. Visitation to nursing homes is still is prohibited and child care facilities still are closed.<br /> 14. Restaurants continue to be restricted to take-out, delivery or drive-thru service.<br /> 15. Churches may conduct services providing they don't exceed a capacity of 50 individuals and all, including the pastor, wear face masks.<br /> 16. The social distancing requirement of at least 6 feet remains in place for general purposes between customers when not directly conducting service.<br /> 17. Employers should encourage frequent breaks to wash hands and employees showing any signs of illness should remain at home.<br /> 18. Employees should wear face masks when interacting with customers.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Consider conducting daily in-person or virtual health checks (e.g., symptoms and/or temperature screening) of employees before they enter the work site.<br /> 1a. Develop and implement a policy to prevent employees from congregating in groups while waiting for screening, and maintain a 6-foot separation between employees<br /> <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> Employees should wear a cloth face covering to cover their nose and mouth in all areas of the business </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Establish policies and practices for social distancing:<br /> 2. Remind employees that people may be able to spread COVID-19 even if they do not show symptoms. Consider all close interactions (within 6 feet) with employees, clients, and others as a potential source of exposure.<br /> 3. Prohibit handshaking, hugs, and fist bumps.<br /> 4. Limit use and occupancy of elevators to maintain social distancing of at least 6 feet.<br /> 5. Encourage the use of outdoor seating areas and social distancing for any small group activities such as lunches, breaks, and meetings. 6.More strict and stringent for specific sectors <br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Provide employees adequate time to wash their hands and access to soap, clean water, and single use paper towels<br /> 1a. Remind employees to wash their hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, they should use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces<br /> 1a. Follow the Guidance for Cleaning and Disinfecting to develop, follow, and maintain a plan to perform regular cleanings to reduce the risk of peoples exposure to the virus that causes COVID-19 on surfaces.<br /> 1b. Routinely clean all frequently touched surfaces in the workplace, such as workstations, keyboards, telephones, handrails, printer/copiers, drinking fountains, and doorknobs<br /> 1c. Provide employees with disposable wipes and other cleaning materials so that they can properly wipe down frequently touched surfaces before each use 2.Industry specific but overall facilities need to be cleaned and disinfected throughout the day<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Employees who appear to have symptoms upon arrival at work or who become sick during the day should immediately be separated from others, provided a face mask if they are not using one, and sent home with instructions and guidance on how to follow-up with their health care professional.<br /> 2. Sick employees should follow CDC-recommended steps. Employees should not return to work until the criteria to discontinue home isolation are met, in consultation with their healthcare provider.<br /> 3. Perform enhanced cleaning and disinfection after anyone suspected or confirmed to have COVID-19 has been in the workplace. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Open Now</strong><br> Restrictions lifted on Elective and Outpatient procedures </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Remained Closed </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="Information Coming Soon"> Information Coming Soon </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-18 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.covid19usvi.com/?utm_source=doh&utm_medium=web&utm_campaign=coronavirus"> Department of Health </a><a target="_blank" href="https://www.vi.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/6th-Supplemental-Exececutive-Order-COVID-19.pdf"> General Guidelines </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Utah')" data-value="49" class="collapsible">Utah</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> No stay at home order for low risk areas. Areas at </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://governor.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/40/2020/05/Executive-Order-Updated-Health-Risk-Status-Phases-Guidelines-1.pdf" target="_blank"> Executive Order 5/27 </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://governor.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/40/2020/05/Phased_Health_Guidelines_V4.5.2_05262020.pdf" target="_blank"> Phased Guidelines for the General Public and Businesses to Maximize Public Health and Economic Reactivation Version 4.5 </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> In yellow areas, all businesses can open if they can meet and adhere to all related guidelines. In orange areas, most business can open if they meet strict guidelines, but some are restricted. See industry specific guidelines: https://governor.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/40/2020/05/Phased_Health_Guidelines_V4.5.2_05262020.pdf </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> 1. Encourage remote work when possible; employers exercise discretion with returning to onsite work.<br /> 2. Employers encourage flexible working arrangements (rotating shifts, remote, etc.). Comply with distancing guidelines. Increased cleaning regimen of high-touch areas. Monitor employees for symptoms and well-being.<br /> 3. Limit unnecessary travel.<br /> 4. Post given signage<br /> 5. Businesses that necessitate on-site work should monitor workforce for symptoms and well-being<br /> 5a. Symptom checking in business interactions and start of shift<br /> 5b. Manager checks each employee for symptoms before every shift with temperatures taken and asks if any member of the employees household has tested positive for COVID-19 in the past 14 days. Log must be kept and available for inspection by the local health officer<br /> 5c. Require employees to self-quarantine when returning from high-risk areas<br /> 6. Maintain the six-foot physical distancing requirements.<br /> 7. Minimize face-to-face interactions. (e.g. utilize drive-thru, install partitions)<br /> 8. Employers provide personal protection equipment such as face coverings, hair nets, gloves, overalls<br /> 9. Regularly and frequently clean and disinfect any regularly touched or shared surfaces and any items that come into contact with customers.<br /> 10. Make hand sanitizer readily available to customers and employees (e.g. at checkout counters and entrances, etc.).<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended for high risk</strong><br> Those who are, or work with, high-risk populations, should undergo daily screening/symptom monitoring, and be tested if they begin to experience COVID-19 symptoms. High-risk populations should take extra precautions to avoid close contact with multiple people. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Those who are, or work with, high-risk populations, should undergo daily screening/symptom monitoring, and be tested if they begin to experience COVID-19 symptoms. High-risk populations should take extra precautions to avoid close contact with multiple people.<br /> 2. Monitor employee symptoms, especially fever. If employees need to take simple medications acetaminophen, ibuprofen, or aspirin, they should take temperature beforehand.<br /> 3. Train managers/leadership to spot symptoms of COVID-19 and to be clear on relevant protocols. 4. Symptom checking of fever (100.4 or above), cough, trouble breathing, sore throat, sudden change in taste or smell, muscle aches or pains<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Face coverings should be worn by employees and patrons, especially when difficult or impossible to maintain 6-foot distance.<br /> 2. Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) should not be shared and should be disposed of properly. 3.More specificity and guidance for individual sectors<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> For orange areas: <br /> 1. Leave home infrequently, stay 6 feet away from others when outside the home.<br /> 2. Employees and volunteers of businesses operate remotely, unless not possible.<br /> 3. High-contact businesses can operate under strict protocols.<br /> 4. Design spaces to maintain 6-foot distance between individuals. <br /> <br /> For yellow areas: <br /> 1. In-person interactions in decreased group sizes that enable all social distancing guidelines to be maintained; social interactions in groups 50 or fewer.<br /> 2. Maintain social distancing when in public settings.<br /> 3. All businesses operational if they can meet and adhere to all related guidelines. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. Promote etiquette for coughing, sneezing, and handwashing; avoid touching face, especially eyes, nose, and mouth; place posters that encourage hand and respiratory hygiene.<br /> 2. Face coverings should be worn by employees and patrons, especially when difficult or impossible to maintain 6-foot distance.<br /> 3. Ensure adequate air circulation and post tips on how to stop the spread of germs.<br /> 4. When possible, discourage sharing of work tools and equipment.<br /> 5. Make a list of high-touch surfaces requiring routine disinfecting and perform routine environmental cleaning (e.g., elevator buttons, workstations, countertops, handrails, doorknobs, breakrooms, bathrooms, common areas), either twice a day or after each use. Keep a logbook of cleaning regimen. Those cleaning should: (Wear gloves, Prior to disinfecting, clean surfaces with soap and water if soiled, Use EPA-approved disinfectant, industrial cleaner, diluted bleach, or alcohol solutions).<br /> 6. Provide disposable disinfecting wipes for employee use on high-touch surfaces; provide no-touch trash bins.<br /> 7. Laundry: wear gloves, use warmest appropriate water setting, dry items completely, do not shake dirty laundry, launder items that have come in contact with COVID-19 separately.<br /> 8. Make hand sanitizer, soap and water, or effective disinfectant readily available. Provide pop-up handwashing stations or facilities where necessary (e.g. open houses, construction sites).<br /> 9. Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) should not be shared and should be disposed of properly.<br /> 10. After using gloves, employees should wash their hands.<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. When possible, discourage sharing of work tools and equipment.<br /> 2. Make a list of high-touch surfaces requiring routine disinfecting and perform routine environmental cleaning (e.g., elevator buttons, workstations, countertops, handrails, doorknobs, breakrooms, bathrooms, common areas), either twice a day or after each use. Keep a logbook of cleaning regimen. Those cleaning should: (Wear gloves, Prior to disinfecting, clean surfaces with soap and water if soiled, Use EPA-approved disinfectant, industrial cleaner, diluted bleach, or alcohol solutions).<br /> 3. Provide disposable disinfecting wipes for employee use on high-touch surfaces; provide no-touch trash bins.<br /> 4. Laundry: wear gloves, use warmest appropriate water setting, dry items completely, do not shake dirty laundry, launder items that have come in contact with COVID-19 separately. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Recommended</strong><br> 1. If an employee is confirmed COVID-19 positive, employers should inform close contact employees while maintaining confidentiality; close contact employees should self-monitor for symptoms for 14 days<br /> 2. Employees who are sick or who appear to have COVID-19 symptoms should be separated from other employees/customers immediately and sent home; immediately clean and disinfect areas the sick employee visited </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Partially Opened </strong><br> Public Health Order Allowing Hospitals and Physicians to Resume Some Elective Surgeries </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Reopening come Fall </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://jobs.utah.gov/covid19/uifaqemployees.pdf"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-18 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://governor.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/40/2020/05/Phased_Health_Guidelines_V4.5.2_05262020.pdf"> Phased Guidelines for the General Public and Businesses </a><a target="_blank" href="https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utahs-moderate-risk-phase/"> Orange Guidelines </a><a target="_blank" href="https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utahs-low-risk-phase/"> Yellow Guidelines </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div></div></div>
<button onclick="handleOutboundLinkClicks(event, 'CNRG click on Vermont')" data-value="50" class="collapsible">Vermont</button> <div class="collapsible-content"><div class="cnt"><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> STAY AT HOME ORDER </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Order - End Date </div> <div class="content_right"> Stay at home order expired - Reopening in progress </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Stay at Home Executive Order </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2012%20TO%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf" target="_blank"> Be Smart/Stay Safe </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Re-Opening Plan </div> <div class="content_right"><a href="https://governor.vermont.gov/covid19response#Restart" target="_blank"> Restart Vermont: Phased Re-Openings </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Current Reopening Phase Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> Open now:<br /> 1. Houses of worship (Drive-in services may continue and Indoor services at 50% capacity)<br /> 2. Food and drink (Restaurants and bars for outdoor dining - If the business already has an outdoor seating permit - will allow service at 50% capacity outdoors, 25% indoor) <br /> 3. Retail (Non-essential retail 25% of capacity)<br /> 4. Personal care Salons, barbershops, etc.<br /> 5. Outdoor and recreation Campgrounds<br /> 6. Child Care </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> GUIDELINES FOR EMPLOYERS </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Overview </div> <div class="content_right"> 1. Employees shall not report to, or be allowed to remain at, work or job site if sick or symptomatic (fever, cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, chills, repeated shaking with chills, muscle pain, sore throat, new loss of taste or smell). <br /> 2. Employees must observe strict social distancing of 6 feet while on the job. Businesses and non-profit or government entities shall ensure customers observe strict social distancing of 6 feet while on location, to the extent possible.<br /> 3. Limit the occupancy of designated common areas, such as break rooms and cafeterias, so that occupants maintain strict social distancing of no less than 6 feet per individual. The employer shall enforce the occupancy limit and require employees to wipe down their area after use or shall ensure cleaning of the common areas at regular intervals throughout the day<br /> 4. Employees must wear face coverings over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others. In the case of retail cashiers, a translucent shield or "sneeze guard" is acceptable in lieu of a mask. Businesses and non-profit and government entities may require customers or clients to wear masks.<br /> 5. Employees must have easy and frequent access to soap and water or hand sanitizer during duration of work, and handwashing or hand sanitization is required frequently including before entering, and leaving, job sites. <br /> 6. All common spaces (when open) and equipment, including bathrooms, frequently touched surfaces and doors, tools and equipment, and vehicles must be cleaned regularly and, when possible, prior to transfer from one person to another, in accordance with CDC guidance. <br /> 7. Prior to the commencement of each work shift, pre-screening and health survey shall be required to verify each employee has no symptoms of respiratory illness (fever, cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, chills, repeated shaking with chills, muscle pain, sore throat, new loss of taste or smell). At the present time non-contact thermometers are in short supply, however employers shall immediately order, and use their best efforts to obtain, thermometers in order to conduct routine temperature checks<br /> 8. Signs must be posted at all entrances clearly indicating that no one may enter if they have symptoms of respiratory illness<br /> 9. When working inside, open doors and windows to promote air flow to the greatest extent possible and limit the number of people occupying a single indoor space. <br /> 10. No more than 2 people shall occupy one vehicle when conducting work. <br /> 11. No symptomatic or COVID-19 positive workers are allowed on site and any worker(s) who have contact with a worker or any other person who is diagnosed with COVID-19 are required to quarantine for 14 days. <br /> 12. All operations shall designate a health officer on-site at every shift responsible for ensuring compliance with the Executive Order and the Addenda thereto and applicable ACCD Guidance. This person shall have the authority to stop or modify activities to ensure work conforms with the mandatory health and safety requirements. <br /> 13. All business, nonprofit and government operations must use remote work whenever possible. <br /> 14. All employees, including those already working (except healthcare workers, first responders, and others already trained in infection control, personal protection/universal precautions), must complete, and employers must document, a training on mandatory health and safety requirements as provided by VOSHA, or another training program that meets or exceeds the VOSHA-provided standard. Employers who need translations of the training have one week from the release of the translated training to complete this requirement. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Testing Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Information not available</strong><br> Information not available </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Symptom Monitoring </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Prior to the commencement of each work shift, pre-screening and health survey shall be required to verify each employee has no symptoms of respiratory illness (fever, cough, and/or shortness of breath). <br /> 2. At the present time non-contact thermometers are in short supply, however employers shall immediately order, and use their best efforts to obtain, thermometers in order to conduct routine temperature checks. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> PPE </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Face coverings should be worn by employees and patrons, especially when difficult or impossible to maintain 6-foot distance.<br /> 2. Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) should not be shared and should be disposed of properly.<br /> 3. After using gloves, employees should wash their hands. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Social Distancing </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Employees must observe strict social distancing of 6 feet while on the job. Businesses and non-profit or government entities shall ensure customers observe strict social distancing of 6 feet while on location, to the extent possible. <br /> 2. Limit the occupancy of designated common areas, such as break rooms and cafeterias, so that occupants maintain strict social distancing of no less than 6 feet per individual. The employer shall enforce the occupancy limit and require employees to wipe down their area after use or shall ensure cleaning of the common areas at regular intervals throughout the day. <br /> 3. No more than 2 people shall occupy one vehicle when conducting work. <br /> 4. Face-to-face staff meetings should be limited, and physical distancing must be observed<br />
</div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Hygiene </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. Employees must have easy and frequent access to soap and water or hand sanitizer during duration of work, and handwashing or hand sanitization is required frequently including before entering, and leaving, job sites. <br /> 2. To the extent possible, provide access to hand washing and/or hand sanitizer for vendors, and customers. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Cleaning </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> 1. The employer shall enforce the occupancy limit and require employees to wipe down their area after use or shall ensure cleaning of the common areas at regular intervals throughout the day.<br /> 2. All common spaces (when open) and equipment, including bathrooms, frequently touched surfaces and doors, tools and equipment, and vehicles must be cleaned regularly and, when possible, prior to transfer from one person to another, in accordance with CDC guidance. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Confirmed Cases </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Required</strong><br> No symptomatic or COVID-19 positive workers are allowed on site and any worker(s) who have contact with a worker or any other person who is diagnosed with COVID-19 are required to quarantine for 14 days. </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="stay_at_home_execution_order_name m-b-10"> OTHER INFORMATION </div><hr><div class="title_left"> Elective Surgery Status </div> <div class="content_right"> <strong>Partially Opened </strong><br> Limited elective procedures would resume </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> School Closure Status </div> <div class="content_right"> Expected to reopen in fall </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Short Term Disability Information </div> <div class="content_right"><a target="_blank" href="https://labor.vermont.gov/covid19/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions"> Link </a></div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Coalitions </div> <div class="content_right"> </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Last Updated Date </div> <div class="content_right"> 2020-06-10 </div> <div class="clearfix m-b-20"></div><div class="title_left"> Sources </div> <div class="content_right sources_link"><a target="_blank" href="https://accd.vermont.gov/news/update-new-work-safe-additions-stay-home-stay-safe-order"> Mandatory Health and Safety Requirements for All Businesses </a><a target="_blank" href="https://labor.vermont.gov/sites/labor/files/doc_library/Protecting%2520the%2520Safety%2520and%2520Health%2520of%2520Workers%2520VOSHA%2520COVID_FINAL%2520%252805.04.2020%2529_0.pdf"> Protecting the Safety and Health of Workers - VOSHA </a><a target="_blank" href="https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19/business/restart/plans"> Business Restart Plans </a></div> <div class="clearfix
